231. my genetic solver is ready
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 23 May 2005 17:55:41 -0000

Hi ! I uploaded the 2.0 version of my genetic solver. The program should now solve any fully scrambled cube in about 30-40 moves. Email me if you are interested in the source code (Fortran), and feel free to test it and report any bug or suggestion ;-) I decided to use only genetic programming and no additional alg is hidden in the source code: this program learns each time how to solve the cube. This is not THE definitive version, but from now on I don't think I will post again on that topic, unless I make an incredible discovery in my secret, genetically modified, cube program factory. Enjoy ! Cyril http://cyril.webzzanine.net/cube/genetic_alg.html PS : I change my vote for SQTM: I couldn't believe my eyes when I saw I had won a category with the solution I posted last week :-)
232. Corner Insertion
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 May 2005 00:54:03 -0000

Hi everyone, I am really trying hard to suss the practice of inserting moves to solve corners. Now, I understand the concept of it, and although Per has spent a lot of time trying to explain it to me, I still can't make them happen by myself. But as I try more and more, I am getting little insights, but still not finding out the whole truth. I try it the commutator way, doing something like PQ P'Q' where Q is a 3 move string, but I'm still not really sure how to find out what P and Q should be. I use stickers with numbers on, so i can make the orientation correct, as Per (and Mirek sometime ago) showed me. Would it be useful for me to know moves for all the different 3 cycles you can have in one layer? Or can you intuitively put them together using this commutator method? It is really frustrating me, especially when some of you guys seem to pick it up really quickly. Once I've got the hang of this, what is the best way to solve a corner 5-cycle? At the moment I am just trying to solve 1->2->3, and then just solving whats left with another 3-cycle. Well, I would be solving them if i could find the insertions :P I hope you can help :) Dan :)
233. Re: Corner Insertion
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 May 2005 04:24:21 -0000

Hi Dan, to know moves for all the different 3 cycles you can have in one layer may be useful but not for now. Some of them take 9 or even 10 moves. You want to insert 3-cycle sequences that are 8-move long. We discussed one exeption here recently (you rather don't think about it now). Often the 3 corners do not fall in one layer when an 8-move commutator is possible. If your Q is 3 moves then its middle move is with the opposite face than P. After you perform such a commutator on the solved cube, you see that one corner in the layer P keeps its P-color in the P- face. Is it P-clear to you? I mean "pretty clear" :-)? The reason I'm telling you this is because it helps you with getting oriented. Two consecutive numbered stickers of 1->2->3->1 should lie in the same face (P of cause). If they do, you have mostly 2 different 8-move commutators that solve the 3-cycle. After some practice you'll be able to see pretty quickly how many moves if any cancel out in each case. Keep trying! Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > Hi everyone, > > I am really trying hard to suss the practice of inserting moves to > solve corners. > > Now, I understand the concept of it, and although Per has spent a > lot of time trying to explain it to me, I still can't make them > happen by myself. But as I try more and more, I am getting little > insights, but still not finding out the whole truth. > > I try it the commutator way, doing something like PQ P'Q' where Q is > a 3 move string, but I'm still not really sure how to find out what > P and Q should be. I use stickers with numbers on, so i can make the > orientation correct, as Per (and Mirek sometime ago) showed me. > > Would it be useful for me to know moves for all the different 3 > cycles you can have in one layer? Or can you intuitively put them > together using this commutator method? It is really frustrating me, > especially when some of you guys seem to pick it up really quickly. > > Once I've got the hang of this, what is the best way to solve a > corner 5-cycle? At the moment I am just trying to solve 1->2->3, and > then just solving whats left with another 3-cycle. Well, I would be > solving them if i could find the insertions :P > > I hope you can help :) > > Dan :)

235. Re: Corner Insertion
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>

Hey Mirek, Thanks for your tips, I was able to use them already! 236. Re: Corner Insertion
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 May 2005 11:35:59 -0000

Let me try with an example. Better hold white at top. Scramble a solved cube like this: R' D R U R' D' R U' Now put a marker on the U(BR) sticker, because that's a sticker that's already on the correct face. It needs to be solved to U(RF), so put a marker on that sticker as well. That sticker needs to go to L(FD) so put a marker on that one as well. Let me show the "forward" commutator first (it's how I like to think of it). What you want to do is replace the U(BR) sticker with the L(FD) sticker without doing any other changes to the U-layer. This can be done with (B' D2 B). Like you pick up a corner of the first layer if you can't do F2L and hold cross at top. You've somewhat swapped two of our three bad pieces. Now you want to do another swap (remember a 3-cycle is just two swaps). So bring the U(RF) sticker to U(BR) so it can play in the next swap instead of the already solved piece. Do U' and undo the first moves, thereby applying the second "swap": (B' D2 B). Now all that's left to do is bring U back with a U move. It helps me a lot to think in terms of stickers, not pieces. Yes, I want to solve pieces, but if I solve just one sticker of a piece then of course the piece is solved, too. That is, if you think of the stickers as being part of a piece, i.e. the U sticker of the URF sticker does belong to U(RF), not at U(FL), for example. Scramble again like above (R' D R U R' D' R U'). You can also do it "backwards". Start with U to let the U(BR) sticker replace the U(RF) sticker inside the U layer. Then replace it with the L(FD) sticker doing (R' D R). Then let the other U sticker participate in the second swap, i.e. do U'. Now do the second swap: (R' D' R). In this case the two possibilities differ only in QTM but sometimes the also differ in HTM. Try this scramble: (R' D R U2 R' D' R U2). The U sticker that's in the D layer needs to go to U(LB) which takes 4 moves, e.g. (D' B D B'). Thus, the whole forward commutator would be: (D' B D B') U2 (B D' B' D) U2. But it's easy to bring it to U(RF) instead of U(LB) so do the backward commutator instead: U2 (R' D R) U2 (R' D' R). I'd recommend you first try a bit to *not* insert a 3-cylce somewhere in the middle of your solution, but only at the end. Just until you get a good feeling for it. Then when you try to insert somewhere in the middle, instead of looking for one sticker being on the correct face, look for two markers on the same face. Finally let me show an ugly one. Hold white at top. Do (R' B' D2 B R). Imagine you want to solve the top layer (because you're a beginner at solving the cube). The white sticker is on the D face which is the worst case. The above sequence can solve this in just five moves. So solve it again and scramble like this: (U2 R' B' D2 B R U2 R' B' D2 B R). You can solve it with this commutator: (R' B' D2 B R) U2 (R' B' D2 B R) U2. Normally for this you'd put markers on U(RF), U(LB) and D(FR) . Alternatively, you could for example put the markers on R(FU), L(BU) and F(RD), which is also a 3-cycle of stickers that would solve the cube. Now we don't have any two markers on the same face, but it's easier to find a nice setup-alg for a nice commutator. Do (R' B2). Now there are two nice commutators, the shorter in QTM is: R' (D L' D') R (D L D'). Undo the setup-moves: (B2 R). Overall it's the same in HTM but we save 2 in QTM. How do you guys take care for the three possible 3-sticker-cycles? I think I might use three differently colored markers in the future. Cheers! Stefan --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > Hey Mirek, > > Thanks for your tips, I was able to use them already! > I still have lots of troubles though, for instance now I am getting > cases where there doesn't appear to be a layer which contains two of > the pieces, or i can cycle them correct but i can get the > orientation correct. > > It hurts my head :( It's like, you don't only have to look for when > the corner pieces are all in the same layer, but you also have to > find when they are in a particular orientation as well! I'm sure > there must be a way of doing it, but i can't find it :( > > Dan :) > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" > <goljan@s...> wrote: > > Hi Dan, > > to know moves for all the different 3 cycles you can have in one > > layer may be useful but not for now. Some of them take 9 or even > 10 > > moves. You want to insert 3-cycle sequences that are 8-move long. > We > > discussed one exeption here recently (you rather don't think about > > it now). Often the 3 corners do not fall in one layer when an 8- > move > > commutator is possible. > > If your Q is 3 moves then its middle move is with the opposite > > face than P. After you perform such a commutator on the solved > cube, > > you see that one corner in the layer P keeps its P-color in the P- > > face. Is it P-clear to you? I mean "pretty clear" :-)? > > The reason I'm telling you this is because it helps you with > getting > > oriented. Two consecutive numbered stickers of 1->2->3->1 should > lie > > in the same face (P of cause). If they do, you have mostly 2 > > different 8-move commutators that solve the 3-cycle. > > After some practice you'll be able to see pretty quickly how many > > moves if any cancel out in each case. > > Keep trying! > > Mirek > > > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" > > <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > > Hi everyone, > > > > > > I am really trying hard to suss the practice of inserting moves > to > > > solve corners. > > > > > > Now, I understand the concept of it, and although Per has spent > a > > > lot of time trying to explain it to me, I still can't make them > > > happen by myself. But as I try more and more, I am getting > little > > > insights, but still not finding out the whole truth. > > > > > > I try it the commutator way, doing something like PQ P'Q' where > Q > > is > > > a 3 move string, but I'm still not really sure how to find out > > what > > > P and Q should be. I use stickers with numbers on, so i can make > > the > > > orientation correct, as Per (and Mirek sometime ago) showed me. > > > > > > Would it be useful for me to know moves for all the different 3 > > > cycles you can have in one layer? Or can you intuitively put > them > > > together using this commutator method? It is really frustrating > > me, > > > especially when some of you guys seem to pick it up really > quickly. > > > > > > Once I've got the hang of this, what is the best way to solve a > > > corner 5-cycle? At the moment I am just trying to solve 1->2->3, > > and > > > then just solving whats left with another 3-cycle. Well, I would > > be > > > solving them if i could find the insertions :P > > > > > > I hope you can help :) > > > > > > Dan :)
237. Re: Corner Insertion
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 May 2005 11:50:14 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > It helps me a lot to think in terms of stickers, not pieces. Yes, I > want to solve pieces, but if I solve just one sticker of a piece then > of course the piece is solved, too. That is, if you think of the > stickers as being part of a piece, i.e. the U sticker of the URF > sticker does belong to U(RF), not at U(FL), for example. Of course I meant "the U sticker of the URF ***piece***". And maybe I should've mentioned I write URF for a piece (which also has the names RFU and FUR) and I write U(RF) for a sticker (which means the U sticker on the URF piece and is different from the R(FU) and the F(UR) stickers on that same piece). Maybe in order to not confuse that with an algorithm I should write U<RF> or so, but it's usually clear from the context, and (RF) is not an easy finger trick anyway ;-) Cheers! Stefan
238. Re: Corner Insertion
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 May 2005 20:57:22 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > I'd recommend you first try a bit to *not* insert a 3-cylce somewhere > in the middle of your solution, but only at the end. Just until you > get a good feeling for it. Oh, and here's an idea how to do it: Split a 25 move computer scramble into 5 parts of 5 moves. This will provide 5 practice cases. For each one, apply the 5 moves, then do a 3-cycle PLL that you know, then undo the 5 moves. Now you have a "random" 3-cycle but the cube is solved otherwise. Cheers! Stefan
239. Re: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: Corner Insertion
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Mon, 30 May 2005 22:19:22 +0100

Hey Stefan, Thanks for all the tips! They have certainly helped. I guess I was being a bit blind or stupid but I was under the impression that you could have solved any corner case using the PQP'Q' in 8 moves. But now I realise depending on Orientation you sometimes need another move or so. But this brings up another confusion... how do i know what to look for when going through my solution to find suitable insertion points? At the moment I try to see when all 3 corner pieces are in 1-layer (layer of the cube, not the definition of layer we used when solving the actual corners), but it seems you could also spot other situations which are not of this type, but if you did a set-up move to get all pieces in one layer, you might then have to undo the set-up move to start the commutator. I just need some concrete rules to use when looking for pieces! Until I get enough experience that I start seeing things a bit easier. But this is really fun to explore! And thank you for the practice idea, it is really clever, wish I had thought of it :P Speak soon! Dan :) ----- Original Message ----- From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...> To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com> Sent: Monday, May 30, 2005 9:57 PM Subject: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: Corner Insertion > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > I'd recommend you first try a bit to *not* insert a 3-cylce > somewhere > > in the middle of your solution, but only at the end. Just until you > > get a good feeling for it. > > Oh, and here's an idea how to do it: Split a 25 move computer scramble > into 5 parts of 5 moves. This will provide 5 practice cases. For each > one, apply the 5 moves, then do a 3-cycle PLL that you know, then undo > the 5 moves. Now you have a "random" 3-cycle but the cube is solved > otherwise. > > Cheers! > Stefan > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
240. Re: Corner Insertion
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 May 2005 22:52:10 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > But this brings up another confusion... how do i know what to look for when > going through my solution to find suitable insertion points? At the moment I > try to see when all 3 corner pieces are in 1-layer (layer of the cube, not > the definition of layer we used when solving the actual corners), Mmh, sorry, I don't understand what you mean here. Actually what you want is two markers on the same face and the third marker not in the layer of that face. Optimally the third marker would also not be on the opposite face, but on an adjacent one. Since there are three 3-sticker-cycles you can use three differently colored sets of three markers each. Let's say you have pink, black and turquoise markers. Example again: Scramble with: R' D R U R' D' R U'. Now put markers on the stickers of the bad pieces. Choose some sticker first and follow its path to know where to put the other two of the same color. Put pink markers on U(RF), L(FD) and U(BR). Put black markers on R(FU), F(DL) and B(RU). Put turquoise markers on F(UR), D(LF) and R(UB). Clear so far? Now let's see how the different marker sets can lead to different solutions: Pink: I see two markers on the U face and the third outside the U layer. Perfect already. Two possibilities: [B' D2 B, U'] [U, R' D R] Black: No two markers on one face, but I can easily reach that with a setup move, for example with R2 bringing two black markers to the F face and one outside the F layer. Let's put F to U with an x rotation just to make things clearer. Then we have two possible nice solutions: [L D' L', U] [U', R' D' R] Of course you'll have to undo the R2 at the end, which will at least cancel out in the second solution. There are other setup moves as well, try to find a nice one and show us! Turquoise: Again no two markers share a face. But with one setup-move we can reach a good state, e.g. with R' or B'. Try to find good commutators that work using these. As you can see, the pink markers lead to the best solutions in this case because already at start two of them were on one face and the third outside of its layer and even on an adjacent face. The black and turquoise markers were slightly slower but of course this won't always be the case. When you go through your solution, trying to insert a 3-cycle, look for two markers of the same color on one face and the third marker of the same color outside its layer and hopefully on an adjacent face. Good luck... uh, I mean... insight and wisdom! And let us know how it's going. Cheers! Stefan > seems you could also spot other situations which are not of this type, but > if you did a set-up move to get all pieces in one layer, you might then have > to undo the set-up move to start the commutator. > > I just need some concrete rules to use when looking for pieces! Until I get > enough experience that I start seeing things a bit easier. But this is > really fun to explore! > And thank you for the practice idea, it is really clever, wish I had thought > of it :P > > Speak soon! > Dan :) > > ----- Original Message ----- > From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> > To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com> > Sent: Monday, May 30, 2005 9:57 PM > Subject: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: Corner Insertion > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > I'd recommend you first try a bit to *not* insert a 3-cylce > > somewhere > > > in the middle of your solution, but only at the end. Just until you > > > get a good feeling for it. > > > > Oh, and here's an idea how to do it: Split a 25 move computer scramble > > into 5 parts of 5 moves. This will provide 5 practice cases. For each > > one, apply the 5 moves, then do a 3-cycle PLL that you know, then undo > > the 5 moves. Now you have a "random" 3-cycle but the cube is solved > > otherwise. > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
241. Re: Corner Insertion
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 30 May 2005 22:58:01 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "c_w_tsai" <c_w_tsai@y... > wrote: > > I have to look around clockwise so I'm > on the D face, and likewise look around the 3 sticker clockwise. Yes, you can just look around clockwise (or counterclockwise) around the corner and pretend the markers are there, but it's confusing me a lot, that's why I had the idea to use 3*3 markers. I think especially for a beginner this should be a good idea. Cheers! Stefan
242. Re: Corner Insertion
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 00:33:54 -0000

Hey! What he means by good insertion points is to see easily whether there is gonna be any cancellation when inserting a corner 3-cycle there. This assumes a basic 8-move corner 3-cycle is at all possible at that specific point. With practice u can see fast what the first and last move will be when u "construct" ur PQP'Q' commutator 3-cycles. Either P or Q could be the 3-move part that replaces one corner in the layer moved by Q or P. If u know the P part will be say R B R' and the Q part is F2 u know that the sequence will start with R and end with F2. If the Q part was simply F then it would instead end with F' (Q' is F' in this case). I agree that the most confusing part can be that there are 3 ways to put on the stickers, and the chance is only 1/3 that 2 stickers will be on the same face when a 8-move corner 3-cycle is possible. Again u see with practice that there is a move that moves one sticker to the other (while not moving the last corner) and that there exists a 3-mover transporting the last sticker to either of the 2 others (being in the same layer), changing only 1 corner in that layer of course. It helps to imagine the layer with the 2 corners as entirely black apart from the 2 corners and the rest of the cube transparent apart from the 3rd corner ;-) It's not easy i know but if u manage u are a long way to find those magic 3-movers :-) In fact it's exactly those cases when the last sticker (on the third corner) can be moved to either of the 2 first 2 stickers (corners) in 3 moves that we have 2 possible 8-move corner 3-cycles with same effect :-) To see this assume the stickers are numbers 1,2,3. 1 and 2 are in the same layer (assume for simplicity in the same face). If moving 3 to 1 in 3 turns first gives the desired cycle then instead moving 3 to 2 first gives the inverse cycle. So if u do that (3 to 2 first) u can reverse ur whole cycle. For obvious reasons this can't be the same sequence as the first, since this sequence will start w moving the layer that has corners w stickers 1 and 2. And the first sequence will not :-) Example if the desired cycle is reached by : R' D' R U' R' D R U then we can also do following to create the inverse cycle : L D' L' U L D L' U'. Inverting the latter gives U L D' L' U' L D L' U which is not same as R' D' R U' R' D R U. Incidentally also R' D' R U2 R' D R U2 has another possible sequence giving same result. Can u work it out (Dan) ? Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" > <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > > > But this brings up another confusion... how do i know what to look > for when > > going through my solution to find suitable insertion points? At the > moment I > > try to see when all 3 corner pieces are in 1-layer (layer of the > cube, not > > the definition of layer we used when solving the actual corners), > > Mmh, sorry, I don't understand what you mean here. > > Actually what you want is two markers on the same face and the third > marker not in the layer of that face. Optimally the third marker would > also not be on the opposite face, but on an adjacent one. > > Since there are three 3-sticker-cycles you can use three differently > colored sets of three markers each. Let's say you have pink, black and > turquoise markers. > > Example again: Scramble with: R' D R U R' D' R U'. Now put markers on > the stickers of the bad pieces. Choose some sticker first and follow > its path to know where to put the other two of the same color. > > Put pink markers on U(RF), L(FD) and U(BR). > Put black markers on R(FU), F(DL) and B(RU). > Put turquoise markers on F(UR), D(LF) and R(UB). > > Clear so far? > > Now let's see how the different marker sets can lead to different > solutions: > > Pink: > I see two markers on the U face and the third outside the U layer. > Perfect already. Two possibilities: > [B' D2 B, U'] > [U, R' D R] > > Black: > No two markers on one face, but I can easily reach that with a setup > move, for example with R2 bringing two black markers to the F face and > one outside the F layer. 243. Re: TMs (round 2)
From: Gatan Guimond <rubiks99@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 03:12:26 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f. > ..> wrote: > > > > There are 2 reasons why I think *QTM is the right choice: > > - Because R and R2 have different effects on the parity signature of > a > > cube configuration, I have problems putting the same label on them. > > Mmh, I'm far from FMC expert but what does parity have to do with FMC? > How do you make use of it? In blindsolving I do care a little bit > about parity, just like in speedsolving I care about fast execution, > but you said yourself we should avoid non-FMC concerns. > > I like STM because when I invent algorithms I think that way. For > example, the PLL where I swap opposite edges I'd *think* about it like > this: > > 1) Bring two down (M2) > 2) Swap them there (D2) > 3) Brign them up again (M2) > 4) Get the other pair in place (U) > 5) Bring two down (M2) > 6) Swap them there (D2) > 7) Brign them up again (M2) > 8) Undo 4) > > Each M2 and D2 looks like one move and for my brain (pretty closely > related to FMC) they are single inseparable steps. > > Cheers! > Stefan Excuse my french language. 246. Re: Corner Insertion
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 31 May 2005 16:54:48 -0000

Yes, you still have only two 8-move commutators doing the same 3-cycle in that case. For Dan: Once you are comfortable solving corner 3-cycles with 8-move commutators (when it is possible), you can start searching for good insertions the way I do it. Here is the know-how. Let the sequence ABCDE...XYZ solves the cube up to 3 corners (cycled). I don't use no middle layer moves here. Stick numbered stickers correspondigly on these corners, 3 or if you like 9 colored stickers, numbers 1,2,3. Start undoing all the moves slowly one by one as Z'Y'X'.... Use a pointer (a pen is not very good) to show on your written sequence where you currently are. At each point, think about the move you're doing as a beginning of an 8-move commutator that can solve the current position the corners are in. If the move does not match your commutator (either one of two, one or none possible), continue. If it matches write it down. Continue until you're back in the scrambled cube. Incentives: you have your cube ready for another solving attempt. Example. Suppose you've done Z'Y'X'...E'. Now you're about to do D' and you notice that [D',Q] (Q is 3 moves) solves the case. Two moves, D D', will cancel out. More you can figure out when practicing on FMC#eightysomething. Happy 3-cycling! Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > I agree that the most confusing part can be that there are 3 ways to > > put on the stickers, and the chance is only 1/3 that 2 stickers will > > be on the same face when a 8-move corner 3-cycle is possible. Again > > u see with practice that there is a move that moves one sticker to > > the other (while not moving the last corner) and that there exists a > > 3-mover transporting the last sticker to either of the 2 others > > (being in the same layer), changing only 1 corner in that layer of > > course. > > Yeah ok, last night I thought about this a bit more and now I > understand it. Will need some more practice, though, or I just see the > 1-move-layer and then read from it which direction I should imagine > the third marker to be rotated. > > > In fact it's exactly those cases when the last sticker (on the third > > corner) can be moved to either of the 2 first 2 stickers (corners) > > in 3 moves that we have 2 possible 8-move corner 3-cycles with same > > effect :-) > > I've read there are always at most two 8-move algs (I think Mirek > wrote it) but I'm still not sure. What about cases where there are two > different 1-move-layers? For example these two commutators have the > same effect: > [F R F', L'] > [U, F' D' F] > > Cheers! > Stefan
247. Corner Insertion (round 2)
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 01 Jun 2005 19:06:06 -0000

Hi everybody! FIrst of all thanks for your helpful comments and tips and examples of commutators in FMC solves. I have said it before to people I know, but I really AM getting the hang of it now! It's really fun searching for commutators now I can spot them a bit easier and not have to think too hard. I have taken all your comments on board, and my system is a bit of a hybrid of methods, like Mirek's pointer and Per's commutators and Stefan's stickers... and also some of my own discoveries, like I labelled each of the centres U B R L F D to help me write down the commutators directly into the same frame of reference as my scramble/solution reference frame, without having another thing to think about. So now I have another question... What routines do you use, when starting from a solution with some corners left? I know you've talked about it before, but I really want to hear it in one post. There are so many different possibilities at each stage. It's even worse when you have to insert 2 3-cycles to make a 5-cycle, because you could find a couple of insertions yielding the same number of moves for the first 3-cycle, which leads to 2 different solutions in which to look for insertions of the 2nd 3- cycle! How do you deal with all the possibilities? And it doesn't stop there... once I've really mastered corners, I might start asking about edge commutators ;) I feel the best way to learn is to always ask lots of questions, my school teachers knew all about that LOL. Once again thanks for everything, and I hope to be a regular competitor in my own competition from now on! I finally got bitten by the FMC bug, about time too ;) Dan :) --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s...> wrote: > Yes, you still have only two 8-move commutators doing the same 3- cycle > in that case. > For Dan: > Once you are comfortable solving corner 3-cycles with 8-move > commutators (when it is possible), you can start searching for good > insertions the way I do it. Here is the know-how. > Let the sequence ABCDE...XYZ solves the cube up to 3 corners (cycled). > I don't use no middle layer moves here. Stick numbered stickers > correspondigly on these corners, 3 or if you like 9 colored stickers, > numbers 1,2,3. Start undoing all the moves slowly one by one as > Z'Y'X'.... Use a pointer (a pen is not very good) to show on your > written sequence where you currently are. At each point, think about > the move you're doing as a beginning of an 8-move commutator that can > solve the current position the corners are in. If the move does not > match your commutator (either one of two, one or none possible), > continue. If it matches write it down. Continue until you're back in > the scrambled cube. Incentives: you have your cube ready for another > solving attempt. > Example. Suppose you've done Z'Y'X'...E'. Now you're about to do D' > and you notice that [D',Q] (Q is 3 moves) solves the case. Two moves, > D D', will cancel out. More you can figure out when practicing on > FMC#eightysomething. > Happy 3-cycling! > Mirek > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > I agree that the most confusing part can be that there are 3 ways to > > > put on the stickers, and the chance is only 1/3 that 2 stickers will > > > be on the same face when a 8-move corner 3-cycle is possible. Again > > > u see with practice that there is a move that moves one sticker to > > > the other (while not moving the last corner) and that there exists a > > > 3-mover transporting the last sticker to either of the 2 others > > > (being in the same layer), changing only 1 corner in that layer of > > > course. > > > > Yeah ok, last night I thought about this a bit more and now I > > understand it. Will need some more practice, though, or I just see the > > 1-move-layer and then read from it which direction I should imagine > > the third marker to be rotated. > > > > > In fact it's exactly those cases when the last sticker (on the third > > > corner) can be moved to either of the 2 first 2 stickers (corners) > > > in 3 moves that we have 2 possible 8-move corner 3-cycles with same > > > effect :-) > > > > I've read there are always at most two 8-move algs (I think Mirek > > wrote it) but I'm still not sure. What about cases where there are two > > different 1-move-layers? For example these two commutators have the > > same effect: > > [F R F', L'] > > [U, F' D' F] > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan
248. Re: Corner Insertion (round 2)
From: "Mikael" <stobe_98@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 02 Jun 2005 06:01:00 -0000

Hello Dan! When I have found something with a corner 3-cycle I put my numbered stickers on the faces and start backtracking. I use Cube Companion to keep track of where I am and doublecheck the commutator. I start with checking if a commutator can be used, if it's possible I check if any moves cancel. If 2 or more moves cancel I write the commutator down. Then I make the next (actually previous if you backtrack ;) turn and repeat the steps above. If there was no insertion cancelling 2 moves or more it's easy to remember where insertions cancelling one move were possible. If I have to solve a 5-cycle I do the same as with a single 3-cycle but I also note which corners are rotated. That way I can do the checking a bit faster. For example if I found a commutator with the corners 1,2 and 3 that cancels 5 moves it's no point trying commutators with those corners that only cancel 3 moves (the insertion points for the next 3-cycle will be exactly the same apart from the alg just inserted). On the other hand if I found a 3 move canceller with corners 4,5 and 1 I would note it down because then I would have different corners for the second cycle giving me totally different insertion points. So 5-cycles are a lot more work than a normal 3 cycle (the same is true for 4-cycles). In this weeks FMC I ended up with a corner 5-cycle. I found one insertion cancelling 4 moves and 3 others cancelling 3 moves (all using different corners) so I had to do the second insertion check 4 times. This time the best overall insertion was using the insertion cancelling 4 moves but quite often I have found better overall cancellations using another insertion than the one giving maximum cancellation. I hope I make any sence and that you get a picture of how I do it, Mikael
249. Re: Corner Insertion (round 2) beginner questions
From: "Mike G" <m.godfrey@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 02 Jun 2005 16:08:12 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Mikael" <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > I use Cube Companion to keep track of > where I am and doublecheck the commutator. Hmmph... I didn't know that was allowed. Maybe "no computers" means "no Cube Explorer" :S Though I guess if you can use "Companion" to check the solution as many times as you like, you could argue that the process you describe was part of the checking. Btw, are you allowed to use a second cube to try out commutators on? Mike
250. Re: Corner Insertion (round 2) beginner questions
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 02 Jun 2005 18:15:15 -0000

Hey! _No computers_ basically means no computer software that helps u in any way to search for moves/sequences. So yes, taking it literally, the companion is not allowed. But i guess most here or many anyway use the companion for various purposes other than the solving bit: -verify correctness of ur sequence/solution -normalise notation to UFRBLD only -check length of ur sequence/solution in all the metrics None of this is really helping u towards finding ur solution :-) In Amsterdam last year 3 cubes were allowed for the fewest moves. No other aids were allowed. But now, if i understand correctly, stickers will also be allowed in fewest moves. So this will help a lot when inserting algs (3-cycles and others!) into ur sequence/solution :D Regards, -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Mike G" <m.godfrey@m...> wrote: > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Mikael" <stobe_98@h...> > wrote: > > I use Cube Companion to keep track of > > where I am and doublecheck the commutator. > > Hmmph... I didn't know that was allowed. Maybe "no computers" means "no > Cube Explorer" :S > > Though I guess if you can use "Companion" to check the solution as many > times as you like, you could argue that the process you describe was > part of the checking. > > Btw, are you allowed to use a second cube to try out commutators on? > > Mike

253. Re: Corner Insertion (round 2) beginner questions

But now, if i understand correctly, > stickers will also be allowed in fewest moves. So this will help a > lot when inserting algs (3-cycles and others!) into ur > sequence/solution :D You know, instead of adding your marker stickers on top of the cube stickers, you could always peel off the cube stickers. Cheers! Stefan P.S. Actually, I think the rules even for speedsolving allow peeling the stickers off and putting them back on solved, or disassembling the puzzle and putting it back together solved. I don't think it'll make much sense for 3x3, but maybe 5x5? Can we disassemble/reassemble a 5x5 in 2 minutes?
254. Re: Corner Insertion (round 2) beginner questions
From: "Mikael" <stobe_98@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 02 Jun 2005 19:06:04 -0000

Hello Jason! --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, Jason Kovacic <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > Hello Name is Jason Kovacic > > So IF you cannot use computers to help you find moves, > then are you allowed to use OLL Algs? Or what about > PLL Algs? I thought that a lot of those were found by > computers. Most of what I have learned about the Cube > has been on the internet, using a computer. You are allowed to use OLL and PLL algs you know, but you are not allowed to search for a specific one on the internet. I'm quite new to FMC so I often end up in a situation I know can be solved in few moves but I don't know those moves. Then I find another solution but learn the new alg so that I can use it next time I get a similar position. But learning algs without understanding how they work give you very limited gains in FMC. It is essential to try to understand how the alg works so that you can modify it to your needs. > Stupid Question; What is a commutator? How does > corner Insertion work? Those are not stupid questions at all. A commutator is a sequence that only manipulates a few cubies (for example 3 corners). A commutator works like this PQP'Q' where P and Q are sequences of moves and ' indicates the inverse of the sequence. Here is an example, lets say P = R U R' and Q = D then you would have R U R' D R U' R' D' (a basic corner 3-cycle). Sometimes commutators are noted {R U R', D} where everything before the comma is P and the rest is Q. The inverse is of course also a commutator (PQP'Q')' = QPQ'P. If you do the example on a solved cube and then apply the inverse of it you will see this. Corner insertion is when you have found a solution that solves everything but a few corners (3 corners wrong is the best) and then backtrack that solution and try to find a spot where to insert a commutator that solves the remaining corners and at the same time cancels out some moves. For a good example check Mireks solution to FMC #82 (read his comments and first solve the scramble without inserting the commutator, then backtrack, do the insertion (notice that a few moves cancel), solve and you will have a fully solved cube ). Edge insertion works the same way. The aim with both is that it's easier to not solve all pieces at once and then solve the remaining ones where it's most beneficial. > THanks A Lot You are welcome, hope I answered your questions. Mikael PS. I will give a more detailed explanation of how I use Cube Companion to doublecheck my commutators so noone thinks I cheat =). First I do all backtracking on paper using multiple cubes to try commutators as I go. When I'm done I insert the best one in my solution and the run it on CC checking the whole solution and the commutator in one go. While searching insertion points I only use CC as my pointer of where in the solution I am.
255. Re: Corner Insertion (round 2) beginner questions
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 02 Jun 2005 19:05:37 -0000

Hello :-) They can't say it's not allowed to use any OLL or PLL alg just because a computer got it first. And who knows if a computer found it or another human a long time ago. Even so, u have memorised that alg so are u to use it ;-) A commutator is a sequence of moves in 4 parts like this : PQP'Q' P is any sequence of moves, so is Q. P' is the inverse sequence of P and Q' is inverse of Q'. So if P = URF and Q=DLB then PQP'Q' = URF DLB F'R'U' B'L'D' = URFDLBF'R'U'B'L'D' :-) Umm for corner insertions read many of the recent posts. There are some very good explanations on how to do it there :-) Basically what u do is to insert a corner 3-cycle somewhere earlier on in order to cancel moves, instead of just simply add it to the end. Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, Jason Kovacic <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > Hello Name is Jason Kovacic > > So IF you cannot use computers to help you find moves, > then are you allowed to use OLL Algs? Or what about > PLL Algs? I thought that a lot of those were found by > computers. Most of what I have learned about the Cube > has been on the internet, using a computer. > > Stupid Question; What is a commutator? How does > corner Insertion work? > > > THanks A Lot > > > > > > __________________________________ > Do you Yahoo!? > Make Yahoo! your home page > http://www.yahoo.com/r/hs

260. Special Team FMC #100
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>, <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 7 Jun 2005 02:11:45 +0100

Hi everyone! The FMC has a new, fresh look, and registration has opened for the special Team Fewest Moves Event which will be held to celebrate FMC #100! Registered competitors will be put into teams of 3, and will be given 5 weeks to solve the special scramble as a team.You can communicate as much as possible via email, phone, or whatever, and if it is possible, you will be teamed with people who live near you so you could even arrange a face to face meeting! You are guaranteed to learn lots from the experience, and you will also have a lot of fun! Absolutely anyone is welcome to take part, and if you are a beginner, you are sure to be teamed up with a more knowledgeable FMC'er so you can get the most out of the competition! All you have to do to take part in this "historic" event is to register your details using the Team FMC registration form. The form is on this page http://www.cubestation.co.uk/fmcresults/teamfmc100.php - or alternatively you can visit www.cubestation.co.uk, click on the Fewest Moves Challenge link in the Red menu panel, and then click the yellow box to get to the Team FMC page. And why not browse around the new look FMC pages while you are there :) Full details of the competition will be emailed to all registered competitors, and registration closes at around FMC week 95, and the scramble will be released at FMC #96. Hope you can take part! Dan Harris :)

From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 8 Jun 2005 11:12:49 +0100

Hi everyone, After a brief period of downtime, the FMC submission form is now back up and running. So you can now submit your solutions in the normal way :) Dan :) - www.cubestation.co.uk
262. FMC #100

Date: Thu, 09 Jun 2005 06:56:12 -0000

Sorry for the other post, of course a blank post was not exactly what I meant ;-) Dan, could you remove it from the forum ? I just wanted to make a suggestion for "forcing" the teamwork to be a bit better distributed : for this FMC (and this one only ...) we could imagine submitting 2 (not necessarly different) solutions in two different metrics (one with slice moves and the other without) and sum the number of moves. I think that it would encourage ppl to try various FMC methods. What do you guys think about it ? --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Mikael" <stobe_98@h...> wrote: > Per: I know submitting multiple solutions wouldn't prevent that all > solutions came from one member but the chance that the same person > would find three starts better than any start the two others come up > with is unlikely. > I do agree that the teamwork would suffer if everybody had to > contribute with one solution. But I still think submitting two > solutions could be a good idea. As these two solution could use two > different approaches (maybe force it?) and there would be a new > challange to find two good solutions to the same scramble not only > one.

What do you guys think > about it ? > > > > > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, > "Mikael" > > <stobe_98@h...> > > > > wrote: > > > > > > > > > Per: I know submitting multiple solutions > wouldn't prevent > > that all > > > > > solutions came from one member but the > chance that the same > > person > > > > > would find three starts better than any > start the two others > > come > > > > up > > > > > with is unlikely. > > > > > I do agree that the teamwork would suffer if > everybody had to > > > > > contribute with one solution. As these two > solution could > > use two > > > > > different approaches (maybe force it?) and > there would be a > > new > > > > > challange to find two good solutions to the > same scramble not > > only > > > > > one. > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > __________________________________________________ Do You Yahoo!? Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around http://mail.yahoo.com
267. FMC #88
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 10 Jun 2005 12:44:44 +0100

Hi all, I'm in a real rush, I won't be able to put the results of FMC #87 up today, but I will post them very soon. Meanwhile I have already launched FMC #88 as I won't be in a position to do it this evening. The Submit button should begin working again at midnight :) Good Luck! Dan :)
268. Re: FMC #100
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 10 Jun 2005 13:46:16 -0000

Hi :-) Yes, both FR'F'R and RUR'U' are commutators :-) A commutator is like this : P Q P' Q' where P is any sequence of moves and so is Q. P' and Q' are the inverse sequences of P and Q respectively. So P' mean the sequence P done backwards, and likewise Q' is sequence Q done backwards. In ur 2 cases both P and Q are single moves, but that's ok. The sequences can be single moves :-) About insertion (of corner 3-cycles) read up on this. There has been many posts about it. It would be nice with a website devoted to explaining insertions in depth. With diagrams and so on. Maybe it's coming some day. Basically an insertion is to do an alg somewhere else instead of at the end. Umm it's not technically the same alg u insert somewhere but an alg moving those same cubies in the same way as u would have done adding at the end. What u try to achieve by insertions is to have move cancellations so that ur solution becomes shorter. Sometimes i end up with 5 unsolved corners that i split into 2 3-cycles and then insert those 2 somewhere to save moves. This does take a long time cause there are many possible combinations to break the 5-cycles into 2 3-cycles. And there are many possible insertion points to check out. But with some experience this is rather fun. The way to find the alg giving u the desired effect is to put extra (numbered) stickers on ur cube on the facelets of the cube and then reverse one move at a time and see if u find an alg that can give u cancellation while (of coz) cycling the cubies like u want. Happy counting moves ;-) -Per K PS! As a curiosity also F B F' B' is a commutator, obviously doing nothing at all. 2 moves or sequences are said to _commute_ when the commutator between them is the identity (doing nothing). An example of 2 commuting sequences is P = R' L' D2 L R, Q = F B D2 F' B'. U can easily verify that in this case P Q P' Q' does nothing. In this case not hard to explain why. Looking carefully u see that P = P' and Q = Q'. And also P Q produces 2 2-cycles on the edges only. So P Q P' Q' is like doing (P Q)*2 and since P Q gives 2 2-cycles then (P Q)*2 = I (identity) Neat ;-) > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, Jason Kovacic <kovacic81@y...> wrote: > --- > Hello Everyone, > > I am interested in being in FMC 100. However, I have > only been in one FMC, so I dont really understand the > method. Also, Im not really familiar with > commutators, insertion, et cetera... > > question; Are FR'F'R and RUR'U' commutators? > > Anyway, sign me up, team me up or whatever. > > Jason Kovacic > >  > > > > > > > > > > Daniel Harris <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote > > Yes, I wouldn't mind posting all the solutions which > > were sent in, if they > > came with explanations, and we can make it a > > showcase of how to solve in > > FMC. > > I am expecting that all the masters will help out > > the newbies and show them > > what it's all about :) > > > > But it will be a competition too, there will be a > > winner ;) > > > > We have 12 people so far, thats 4 teams, continue to > > spread the word!] > > > > Dan :) > > > > ----- Original Message ----- > > From: "c_w_tsai" <c_w_tsai@y...> > > To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com> > > Sent: Friday, June 10, 2005 1:20 AM > > Subject: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: FMC #100 > > > > > > > If there turns out to be many people who > > participate, maybe we could > > > use this as an opportunity to show others who are > > new what the fmc > > > is about.. instead of the fierce competition that > > maybe we had in > > > mind. > > > > > > So maybe it won't be so bad if there are > > inexperienced players who > > > aren't able to contribute much.. if they can learn > > something and > > > participate later on we can get more competition > > > > > > Dan how many people have signed up so far? > > > > > > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, > > "Gilles Roux" > > > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > > > > > > I suggest an unlimited number of solutions. > > > > The shortest will win, but let's make this FMC > > special and try to > > > > submit other artistic or fun solutions, be > > inventive! > > > > > > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, > > "Cyril Castella" > > > > <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > > > > > Sorry for the other post, of course a blank > > post was not exactly > > > what > > > > > I meant ;-) Dan, could you remove it from the > > forum ? 269. Mirek solution FMC #87
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 11 Jun 2005 23:30:53 -0000

Hi! Mirek, after ur marvellous 12 move start U2 F R' B R' F' L2 D' F2 D' F L there is a rather short finish like this: L' D' L F' L' D L2 F' D' F2 L'. This also cancels 2 moves giving a total of only 21 moves. U were really close to creaming this weeks solution ;-) By the way im quite sure there might be a better corners insertion for Sebastion but i promised not to look :D You might both have beaten me last week :-) Cheers! -Per
270. Re: Mirek solution FMC #87
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 12 Jun 2005 14:52:33 -0000

Hi Per, I was almost sure that I could do better after my first 11 moves (those are pretty easy to find). The rest can be solved as D' L F' L' D L2 F' D' F2 L' as you pointed out. Did you ask Cube Explorer or you saw it? These moves are very hard to find (!), at least for me. I was sure that 15 moves was too much because I found several solutions of that length. I also started to look at the inverse position obtained as L F' L F' U F2 D' F' D F2 U' F D' F2 L'. Here is one way how to get its optimal solution: The first move is rather obvious - L, then make the UR corner of F face as F2 D F L' F, then L' and finish three pairs as commutator [L F' L', D']. Putting it all together - L F2 D F L2 D' L F L' D which is the inverse of what I needed to win with 21-move solution that would be even with the unoficial world record you already have. Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hi! > > Mirek, after ur marvellous 12 move start U2 F R' B R' F' L2 D' F2 D' F > L there is a rather short finish like this: L' D' L F' L' D L2 F' D' > F2 L'. This also cancels 2 moves giving a total of only 21 moves. U > were really close to creaming this weeks solution ;-) > > By the way im quite sure there might be a better corners insertion for > Sebastion but i promised not to look :D > > You might both have beaten me last week :-) > > Cheers! > > -Per

274. FMC prizes
From: <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>,<speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Tue, 14 Jun 2005 10:14:36 +0100

Hi everyone! In association with www.cubesmith.com, www.cubestation.co.uk is proud to annouce that from next week we will be offering small prizes to the winners of each metric each week in the FMC! www.cubesmith.com is a small yet rapidly growing enterprise manufacturing custom cube stickers for the various shapes and sizes of rubik's puzzles. Each week we will offer small prizes such as set of stickers or tiles, for the various cubes. Let's face it, everyone will need some replacerment stickers sometime! So why not have a practice at this week's FMC scramble (week #88) which is listed on the FMC page at www.cubestation.co.uk , in preparation for the following prize FMC's to come! Check the FMC newswire for more details as I get a chance to post them :) Good Luck! Dan Harris - www.cubestation.co.uk :) ----------------------------------------- Email provided by http://www.ntlhome.com/
275. My #87 solution
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 15 Jun 2005 20:53:54 -0000

Hi Dan ! you made a little typo in my solution move count : STM result is 28 instead of 38 ... Btw, did anyone had a look at my edge 3-cycle insertion after the 22 moves I mention ? I have no real feeling about edges cycles, and I wonder if it's possible to cancel more moves and get a better solution ... Thanks ! Cyril
276. Re: My #87 solution
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 17 Jun 2005 14:33:13 -0000

Hi you! I looked at the edges. I can't tell you what to do after those 22 moves. But I suggest to do L'FLFB'U'F'UF'B before them. You gain in QTM which will help once multiple submitions are allowed. In HTM it is still 30. Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > Hi Dan ! > you made a little typo in my solution move count : STM result is 28 > instead of 38 ... > Btw, did anyone had a look at my edge 3-cycle insertion after the 22 > moves I mention ? I have no real feeling about edges cycles, and I > wonder if it's possible to cancel more moves and get a better solution > ... Thanks ! > > Cyril

278. Re: My #87 solution
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 18 Jun 2005 13:51:54 -0000

Hi Cyril! After ur 22 moves like this : B' L U2 R' D B R L2 D2 L' D2 F' D F' L D' L' D2 F D.F2 D' u can insert the following at the dot : R2 U2 L2 B L2 U2 R2 F This gives u a 29 move solution, cancelling 1 move only. But as pointed out by Mirek its also worth thinking about qtm (or other metrics) also. Im getting more and more convinced that corner finishing is indeed the best way of FMC-ing :-) (There are exceptions to anything though ... ) Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s...> wrote: > Hi you! > I looked at the edges. I can't tell you what to do after those 22 > moves. But I suggest to do L'FLFB'U'F'UF'B before them. You gain in > QTM which will help once multiple submitions are allowed. In HTM it is > still 30. > Mirek > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" > <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > > Hi Dan ! > > you made a little typo in my solution move count : STM result is 28 > > instead of 38 ... > > Btw, did anyone had a look at my edge 3-cycle insertion after the 22 > > moves I mention ? I have no real feeling about edges cycles, and I > > wonder if it's possible to cancel more moves and get a better solution > > ... Thanks ! > > > > Cyril
279. One of the most elegant and shortest
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 18 Jun 2005 15:06:34 -0000

Per, your #88 solution is very interesting - elegant. You should win a prize for it! BTW, how did you come up with the first 6 moves? It can be written as (U'D' F'B' L'R') (R' U' R' D2 R U R) (R U2 R D2) (F' U' R' B2 D' F2 U2). This also reminds me an interesting task: Solve the scrambled cube with single right moves only. (Or with left ones only.) For example such a solution for R F' U' F' R F L2 U2 B' R2 U' L B R2 D' R2 L2 U' D R2 is L U F R U F U B F L R D F D F D F L R B U R U R U L D F L D F R D B L B D L R U R B U. I've never tried to develop a set of algorithms for this. Mirek
280. Re: One of the most elegant and shortest
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 19 Jun 2005 18:53:00 -0000

Umm ... I must make sure to win prize by winning again sometime soon. The prize are up from this week onwards only ;-) Interesting way u rewrote my solution Mirek. I hadn't thought of that. In fact i had thought the solution was quite ugly since it uses many half turns. And the insertions also worked out by many half turns in them. It was quite nice that i inserted first 3-cycle exactly in the middle of the sequence, and also the second 3-cycle was inserted right in the middle of the first insertion. So there was so symmetry in that respect. Having so good cancellations when there are relatively few possible insertion points i would say is really lucky. It's not easy to say exactly how i came up with those 6 first moves. Working on edges is quite different from working w blocks first. There is larger variation in how u approach it. And u reach to the "endgame" faster than u would do starting w blocks. My approach is sorta pure engineering. I know what are good starts for plundering w insertions afterwards. So im just happy find starting a start like that. This approach also leads to less readable final solutions (i guess). Solutions that are short and have no insertion tricks in them are inherently more beautiful IMHO. But it's all about the length of the solution anyway. There's no prize for beauty. Lol ... I'm more interested in the "clockwise solving". How do u come up with a solution like u have shown? I would have no easy way to deal with that. Except real lengthy sequences i guess. Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s...> wrote: > Per, > your #88 solution is very interesting - elegant. You should win a prize > for it! BTW, how did you come up with the first 6 moves? > It can be written as (U'D' F'B' L'R') (R' U' R' D2 R U R) (R U2 R D2) > (F' U' R' B2 D' F2 U2). > This also reminds me an interesting task: > Solve the scrambled cube with single right moves only. (Or with left > ones only.) For example such a solution for R F' U' F' R F L2 U2 B' R2 > U' L B R2 D' R2 L2 U' D R2 is > L U F R U F U B F L R D F D F D F L R B U R U R U L D F L D F R D B L B > D L R U R B U. > I've never tried to develop a set of algorithms for this. > Mirek
281. Re: One of the most elegant and shortest
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 20 Jun 2005 17:02:28 -0000

I think "clockwise solving" is more practical than counterclockwise, too. It's shorter when you write it down and it does not cause you old cube with loose screws to fall apart. How I came up with the solution? I gotcha! The scrambling moves are the solution for what you think was scrambling. ;-) Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Umm ... > > I must make sure to win prize by winning again sometime soon. The > prize are up from this week onwards only ;-) > > Interesting way u rewrote my solution Mirek. I hadn't thought of that. > In fact i had thought the solution was quite ugly since it uses many > half turns. And the insertions also worked out by many half turns in > them. It was quite nice that i inserted first 3-cycle exactly in the > middle of the sequence, and also the second 3-cycle was inserted right > in the middle of the first insertion. So there was so symmetry in that > respect. Having so good cancellations when there are relatively few > possible insertion points i would say is really lucky. > > It's not easy to say exactly how i came up with those 6 first moves. > Working on edges is quite different from working w blocks first. There > is larger variation in how u approach it. And u reach to the "endgame" > faster than u would do starting w blocks. My approach is sorta pure > engineering. I know what are good starts for plundering w insertions > afterwards. So im just happy find starting a start like that. This > approach also leads to less readable final solutions (i guess). > Solutions that are short and have no insertion tricks in them are > inherently more beautiful IMHO. But it's all about the length of the > solution anyway. There's no prize for beauty. Lol ... > > I'm more interested in the "clockwise solving". How do u come up with > a solution like u have shown? I would have no easy way to deal with > that. Except real lengthy sequences i guess. > > Cheers! > > -Per > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" > <goljan@s...> wrote: > > Per, > > your #88 solution is very interesting - elegant. You should win a > prize > > for it! BTW, how did you come up with the first 6 moves? > > It can be written as (U'D' F'B' L'R') (R' U' R' D2 R U R) (R U2 R > D2) > > (F' U' R' B2 D' F2 U2). > > This also reminds me an interesting task: > > Solve the scrambled cube with single right moves only. (Or with left > > ones only.) For example such a solution for R F' U' F' R F L2 U2 B' > R2 > > U' L B R2 D' R2 L2 U' D R2 is > > L U F R U F U B F L R D F D F D F L R B U R U R U L D F L D F R D B > L B > > D L R U R B U. > > I've never tried to develop a set of algorithms for this. > > Mirek
282. Re: One of the most elegant and shortest
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 20 Jun 2005 16:22:40 -0000

I think "clockwise solving" is more practical than counterclockwise, too. It's shorter when you write it down and it does not cause you old cube with loose screws to fall apart. How I came up with the solution? I gotcha! The scrambling moves are the solution for what you think was scrambling. ;-) Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Umm ... > > I must make sure to win prize by winning again sometime soon. The > prize are up from this week onwards only ;-) > > Interesting way u rewrote my solution Mirek. I hadn't thought of that. > In fact i had thought the solution was quite ugly since it uses many > half turns. And the insertions also worked out by many half turns in > them. It was quite nice that i inserted first 3-cycle exactly in the > middle of the sequence, and also the second 3-cycle was inserted right > in the middle of the first insertion. So there was so symmetry in that > respect. There > is larger variation in how u approach it. And u reach to the "endgame" > faster than u would do starting w blocks. My approach is sorta pure > engineering. I know what are good starts for plundering w insertions > afterwards. So im just happy find starting a start like that. This > approach also leads to less readable final solutions (i guess). > Solutions that are short and have no insertion tricks in them are > inherently more beautiful IMHO. (Or with left > > ones only.) For example such a solution for R F' U' F' R F L2 U2 B' > R2 > > U' L B R2 D' R2 L2 U' D R2 is > > L U F R U F U B F L R D F D F D F L R B U R U R U L D F L D F R D B > L B > > D L R U R B U. > > I've never tried to develop a set of algorithms for this. > > Mirek
283. Re: One of the most elegant and shortest
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 20 Jun 2005 22:37:32 -0000

(see below) --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s...> wrote: > I think "clockwise solving" is more practical than counterclockwise, > too. It's shorter when you write it down and it does not cause you old > cube with loose screws to fall apart. > How I came up with the solution? I gotcha! The scrambling moves are > the solution for what you think was scrambling. ;-) > Mirek Hahahahahaha !!! Oh yes of course ;-) I was wondering actually why the scramble wasn't the standard length og 25 or 30 or 40 :D But seriously how would we come up with "short" solutions for clockwise solving? I recall there was some discussion about thise in the speedsolving group a long time ago (last yr most likely). But the focus of discussion was only to show that solving is possible. So some algs were derived for stuff like edge-flip, corner-twist, simple cycles ... But not how to combine all this to feasible length overall solutions. Hmm ... -Per > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Umm ... > > > > I must make sure to win prize by winning again sometime soon. I know what are good starts for plundering w insertions > > afterwards. So im just happy find starting a start like that. 286. Re: Congratz Mirek!
From: "Sebastian Dumitrescu" <portoseb37@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 26 Jun 2005 09:09:54 -0000

> Can somebody look at an interesting start for the FMC #89, L D' F' D > F2 D F2 with possibly D' B' ? I did not succeed. Hi Mirek, First of all, congratulations to the winners! I hope though that prize FMCs won't stop just because there's nore than one winner every time. Now to the point: I tried a lot to get something out of L D' F' D F2 D F2 D' B', and here's what I found out. Notice that the move sequence D' F' D F2 D F2 D' B' solves all the pieces that are part of the DR 2x2x3 block. That means that no matter how we move the L and U faces before applying this sequence, those pieces will be solved. So I naturally thought about finding some moves that will actually solve the cube. I didn't manage to find that, I found B L B' L U L2 U2 L U (D' F' D F2 D F2 D' B') which leaves five corners, and L U2 L' U L U' L' U L U (D' F' D F2 D F2 D' B') which leaves five edges. Since those edges were part of that two-generator for 10 moves, I expected to find a good position for a 5-cycle of edges (belonging to the F U F' B L' B' family), but I didn't. I had already found my 23 STM, 26 HTM solution, and this 5-cycle had good chances of lowering both. I will let you find out by yourselves how one can see which move sequence to apply at the beginning of the solution. It's easy and interesting. This approach is somehow the complementary of the block style. It might be a bit easier to use this one rather than normal blocks. I'll see about it in FMC 91. Sebastian
287. Re: speed fmc
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 10:29:08 -0000

Hmmm ... Good it wasn't ur first try cause that would have been a killer score for speed fmc :D 25 moves is really good. Now u have tempted me to have a look... I had managed to promise myself not spend time on it. I spend ages on the normal rounds, so it was nice to have a speed- round ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "c_w_tsai" <c_w_tsai@y...> wrote: > Too bad it's a speed-fmc week.. I found a nice 25 move solution on my > second try :(
288. FMC # 89 solution by Dan Harris - how to continue please?
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 11:01:14 -0000

Hey everyone, Recently as you know, I've been trying the techniques of corner insertion to optimise my solves. Last week FMC #89, I didn't have time to come up with much because I was spending most of my time with Joel, but on the trainwhen I travelled to meet him in London, I did come up with the following: Scramble: F R2 B R (U' R' L2)*5 B2 L2 R B2 D2 (U2 F2 D)*5 R' U D' R Solution: R' B U' L2 R F L' D F2 D' B' L B2 D F' D F L D' L2 D' L D L' D' L D' = 27 moves with 3 edges left. I don't really know how to insert edges, and I don't know the kind of tricks like PQP'Q' for the corners. So any help would be greatly appreciated :) Dan :) - www.cubestation.co.uk FMC!
289. More about FMC #89
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 2005 03:45:21 -0000

Sebastian, this is interesting approach. Why can't I get it? D' F' D F2 D F2 D' B' solves all the pieces that are part of the DR ? Their orientation does not matter for now. The RD-edge piece is missing, though. And you apply your sequence B L B' L U L2 U2 L U before the above. Can you explain it to me? Anyway, the position after my 9 moves is not an easy one. I tried your first suggestion B L B' L. U L2 U2 L U _ D' F' D F2 D F2 D' B'. +5 corners, and I found only L' D R' D' L D R D', B D' B' U' B D B' U to insert at the dots => (28,33,26); not very short. Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Sebastian Dumitrescu" <portoseb37@h...> wrote: > > Can somebody look at an interesting start for the FMC #89, L D' F' D > > F2 D F2 with possibly D' B' ? That means that no matter how we move the L and U faces > before applying this sequence, those pieces will be solved. So I > naturally thought about finding some moves that will actually solve > the cube. I didn't manage to find that, I found B L B' L U L2 U2 L U > (D' F' D F2 D F2 D' B') which leaves five corners, and L U2 L' U L U' > L' U L U (D' F' D F2 D F2 D' B') which leaves five edges. Since those > edges were part of that two-generator for 10 moves, I expected to find > a good position for a 5-cycle of edges (belonging to the F U F' B L' > B' family), but I didn't. 290. Re: More about FMC #89
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 29 Jun 2005 23:11:12 -0000

I got it. It's basically inserting a set of moves that touch only those pieces that have not been solved yet. Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "c_w_tsai" <c_w_tsai@y...> wrote: > Right after the scramble, look at the pieces in the 2x2x3.. After > the sequence, look where they went. They've all gone to their > correct places. > > Now start the scramble with: D' F' D F2 D F2 D' B'. You'll see that > the DR 2x2x3 is solved. Then try to solve. This is probably how > Sebastian found these two sequences. > > This is a really interesting approach, to say the least... > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" > <goljan@s...> wrote: > > Sebastian, > > this is interesting approach. Why can't I get it? D' F' D F2 D > > F2 D' B' solves all the pieces that are part of the DR ? Their > > orientation does not matter for now. The RD-edge piece is missing, > > though. I found later that i could have inserted the corners 3 moves from the end and saved 4 moves easily. It was like this: 10 minutes for a 41 move > solution, then I tried again later since the scramble showed > potential, found a lucky 19 move sequence that left 3 unsolved > corners in ~10 minutes, then I lost my place backtracking and had to > redo the scramble before finding a good insertion point > > hmmm, now that I think about it, I guess it could have been a > potential winner. I estimate the total time was like 30 minutes. 297. FMC Speed rule question
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 1 Jul 2005 09:39:18 -0700

The FMC Spped rules say "The clock starts as soon as you make your first move". Does that mean you're allowed to "preinspect" the position for unlimited time before you start twisting? That seems dangerous considering the growing number of blind fold cubers. - - - - - - - - - - - - "The mind is like a parachute. It doesn't work unless it's open." --- Frank Zappa Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com
298. RE: [fewestmoveschallenge] FMC Speed rule question
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 1 Jul 2005 18:07:53 +0100

Yes Lars, You are quite right. I think it is about time that the rules were made clear, I better write a little set very soon. Currently the rules imply you're allowed to do this, but I don't want it. So that will be written in the rules. Dan :) -----Original Message----- From: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com [mailto:fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Lars Petrus Sent: 01 July 2005 17:39 To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com Subject: [fewestmoveschallenge] FMC Speed rule question The FMC Spped rules say "The clock starts as soon as you make your first move". Does that mean you're allowed to "preinspect" the position for unlimited time before you start twisting? That seems dangerous considering the growing number of blind fold cubers. - - - - - - - - - - - - "The mind is like a parachute. It doesn't work unless it's open." --- Frank Zappa Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com Yahoo! Groups Links

300. Speed FMC Rules

301. Re: Speed FMC Rules
From: "Sebastian Dumitrescu" <portoseb37@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 01 Jul 2005 21:37:32 -0000

Hi there, I have two questions. One for Dan and one for Gilles. For Dan: I understand from the speed FMC rules you just wrote that the solution we submit must be the last solution we find, and that if we want to further search for a better solution, we must abandon the solution we just found. This makes e.g. insertions more risky than they are already, and I don't think that would be correct. What if we find the next solution after an hour, are we not allowed to come back to the first one? For Gilles: how do you manage to find and write solutions in such a short time? You said in your quote that it's 1 minute for the solution (one move in less than two seconds on average), and two minutes for writing it down. How do you write it down? Do you memorize it? Or do yo rescramble the cube and write it the second time you go through it? Sebastian
302. RE: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: Speed FMC Rules
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 1 Jul 2005 22:44:02 +0100

HI Seb, *sigh* this was the hardest bit to find the right words for, and it seems like I have failed. And I'm a native speaker of English... The crucial point is this: You don't have to abandon a solution once you start looking for a new one. It's perfectly valid to submit any solution that you have found. BUT you can't submit the time you found it at if you then continued looking elsewhere. You MUST submit the total time you spent searching the cube, even if it was wasted time leading to nothing :) I hope this is clear at last! Dan :) -----Original Message----- From: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com [mailto:fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Sebastian Dumitrescu Sent: 01 July 2005 22:38 To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com Subject: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: Speed FMC Rules Hi there, I have two questions. One for Dan and one for Gilles. For Dan: I understand from the speed FMC rules you just wrote that the solution we submit must be the last solution we find, and that if we want to further search for a better solution, we must abandon the solution we just found. This makes e.g. insertions more risky than they are already, and I don't think that would be correct. What if we find the next solution after an hour, are we not allowed to come back to the first one? For Gilles: how do you manage to find and write solutions in such a short time? You said in your quote that it's 1 minute for the solution (one move in less than two seconds on average), and two minutes for writing it down. How do you write it down? Do you memorize it? Or do yo rescramble the cube and write it the second time you go through it? Sebastian Yahoo! Groups Links

From: "Sebastian Dumitrescu" <portoseb37@...>

Date: Fri, 01 Jul 2005 21:59:46 -0000

> It's perfectly valid to submit any solution that you have found. > BUT you can't submit the time you found it at if you then continued looking > elsewhere. You MUST submit the total time you spent searching the cube, even > if it was wasted time leading to nothing :) > > I hope this is clear at last! This is exactly my opinion! Thanks! :D Sebastian

305. RE: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: FMC Speed rule question
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 2 Jul 2005 10:49:56 +0100

Hi Mirek, Firstly, yes FMC #91 is again a Speed FMC! I thought we could all do with the practice ;) I think I have made the rules pretty clear on this point though. In the rules it says "Once you have scrambled your cube for the first time, you are allowed time (no more than 5 seconds) to verify that you have scrambled the cube correctly" And "You are NOT allowed any pre-inspection in the time between scrambling your cube, and starting the stopclock. All inspection and mental manipulation must be made while the stopclock is running" So no, you can't write down moves you are possibly going to make. Your first interpretation is right, you start the clock with your first look at the scrambled cube. Dan :) -----Original Message----- From: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com [mailto:fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of mirek_goljan Sent: 02 July 2005 04:46 To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com Subject: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: FMC Speed rule question Hi, Dan, I missed this interpretation and always started the clock with my first look at the scrambled cube (I scrambled not watching it). The possibility of starting the clock with the first move will help me a lot. Can I even write down moves that I am possibly going to make? Second question: Is really FMC #91 a speed FMC again?
