So > that will be written in the rules. > > Dan :) > > -----Original Message----- > From: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com > [mailto:fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Lars Petrus > Sent: 01 July 2005 17:39 > To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com > Subject: [fewestmoveschallenge] FMC Speed rule question > > The FMC Spped rules say "The clock starts as soon as you make your > first move". > > Does that mean you're allowed to "preinspect" the position for > unlimited time before you start twisting? That seems dangerous > considering the growing number of blind fold cubers. > > - - - - - - - - - - - - > "The mind is like a parachute. 306. Re: FMC Speed rule question (amendment ?)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 02 Jul 2005 13:55:45 -0000

Hey Dan/Everyone !! Then i have one idea (again). Why not on the FMC homepage show only the scramble? And have a link to the applet of the scrambled cube. Then we can set up our cube according to scramble without having seen what it looks like. Already when we see the applet we immediately break the rules by making "mental calculations". At least i can't avoid doing that. When there is easy 2x2x2 i always see it before setting up the scramble on my own cube. It's just an idea, not a big deal ;-) I would prefer some amendment to the rules, where it will potentially pay off to look further and find improvements to ur solution that might pay off without having to suffer if u fail with that. So say u have 40 moves after 10 minutes > score 43. And u decide to keep looking. And then u have 35 moves after say 30 minutes. This however gives u score of 45. And u carry on for 5 more minutes and find a 30 move solution. U have now spent 35 minutes which gives u 12 points for the time so 42 points in total. Now u decide to not look any further. So u can submit ur 42 points solution. However if u hadn't found ur 30 move solution u could still have submitted the 40 moves after 10 minutes. (With current rules u would have to submit 40 moves and 35 minutes > 52 points!!!) IMHO i think this is much more fair. And it adds more fun to the challenge. Of course spending *infinite* time does not pay off as u would need a solution with negative lenghth :-P What do u other guys think about this ? Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > Hi Mirek, > > Firstly, yes FMC #91 is again a Speed FMC! I think you overlooked your shortest solution that you should submit in your toy example - 35 moves and 35 minutes > 47 points. I don't agree that we need to change rules now. Let's get used to the current rules and see later how many people like it or not. It seems like the best strategy is to spent less than 12 minutes and try as many times as possible and - the most important - be lucky. This also means that anyone can win, which is good now when the winner takes a little prize. Ur point is that if i didn't find the 30 and following current rules then yes what i had is still the 35 moves obtained at 30 mins, but now the time is 35. So with current rules i have to submit that and not the 40 moves after 10 minutes. With my amendment there is no penalty even for searching in vain after the 30 moves and 35 minutes. 309. Re: Speed FMC Rules
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 04 Jul 2005 08:56:26 -0000

> > For Gilles: how do you manage to find and write solutions in such a > short time? You said in your quote that it's 1 minute for the solution > (one move in less than two seconds on average), and two minutes for > writing it down. How do you write it down? Do you memorize it? Or do yo > rescramble the cube and write it the second time you go through it? > I wrote moves, max 3 or 4 at a time, just after turning the layers. It's much faster, because you don't need to rescramble the cube, and if you need to backtrack (that's what I did after an uninteresting F3 sequence) it's like working with a LIFO stack. 32 STM was perfect (i.e. lucky), so I didn't try to improve and stopped the timer. After, I only changed L'L' to L2. I wrote "1 minute for the solution" because I guess that's the time I would have spent on it without having to write it down. I practiced twice (with different scrambles! :-) ) before trying it, because I'm not a speedwriter. Opinion about the rules: They should follow the tournament regulations. I mean that the timer should start as soon as the competitor can see the scrambling sequence (or a display of the scrambled cube), and stop when the final solution is written down, ready to be submitted. I still don't know what to think about "time points". If you don't want to get any, as I wrote before this event is mainly speedscrambling and speedwriting. I feel it would be more interesting for many people here (not for me, but for the FMC champions) with lighter time penalities (penalty points starting at 10 minutes, and non linear progression). FMC Prize: Give it to another competitor please. Unofficial competitions are better without rankings and prizes :-) Gilles.
310. I need your cpu time ;-)
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 06 Jul 2005 10:52:46 -0000

Hi ! Actually the title is not a joke, I would greatly appreciate if you could help me with my genetic solver project. One solve for a 30-moves scramble takes about 3 hours on my computer, and my aim is to test the program on 100 random scrambles ... So if you are kind enough for helping me, here is what you can do : 1)Download the 2.1 version of the program : http://cyril.webzzanine.net/cube/genetic21.exe It's a simple windows executable, virus-free (I swear :) ), about 430 ko 2)Launch the program from your hard drive and enter the following parameters : 1 [enter], then 50000 [enter], then 30 [enter] : this leads to a 30-moves random scramble, with each 2x2x3 location searched for 50000 generations 3)Once the program is over, you'll see a sentence telling that "the cube was solved in XXX moves", meaning that it's done. A new file called results.txt should have been created in the same folder as the genetic21.exe file. It contains the scramble, and the different phases of the solution found. Save it with any other name (since results.txt is emptied at the start of each new simulation), and once you have some results you can email them to me at cyrilca [at] caramail [dot] com The program does not require a lot of cpu and memory, one is able to work normally when it's running... I feel like the guys in charge of the SETI@Home project, even if the goal is here slightly different ! Many thanks to the FMC community for helping me in that project ! cyril PS : and of course all suggestions are welcome, even if there are lots of things I already would like to implement without having time to do so ...
311. Re: I need your cpu time ;-)
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 07 Jul 2005 17:30:08 -0000

Well, I downloaded your genetic solver, run it on my fast notebook (it's Pentium something like 1.8 GHz, not sure now) and kept checking if the program was running. After more than 6 hours I got tired and canceled the job. I conclude this suggestion: show an estimated total time the calculations will take. If it's not possible, show some information about how far the calculations are. It's well possible that I canceled the job very close to the finish because I had no clue how far the finish was. I've been running the program on Pentium 3.4 GHz for 2 hours now. Whuooooo, it finished and I don't know when. Can't you show the total time? I could run the program overnight on this PC if you supported multiple runs. This is what you should do if you want me to run it more than twice. :-) Are you sure it's any faster than a random search in each phase? The resulting 39 moves is what we can often do under one minute. With a help of your program it takes hours. I know, it's a project on genetic algorithms ;-). 312. Re: I need your cpu time ;-)
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 08 Jul 2005 17:58:50 -0000

Hi Mirek ! I really like this kind of message, especially your last sentence : It makes me think to my boss, when I have to explain why do I find interesting what I'm making :) Concerning your first 6 hours run, I guess it was a "bad" case. What I call a bad case is when you solve the 2x2x3 and are left with a tricky position (ie non trivial orientation of quite a lot of edges and permutation of corners to enter into the 2-gen group). In these cases, the convergence is stopped until a solution for that given stage is found. Since no alg is entered in the memory (it's a deliberate choice ...), it can be slow, but in my knowledge it has never failed when I gave it enough time for searching. Concerning the elepsed time, it's quite the same from a run to another. You can keep a track of the steps in the DOS-like window : 1) 12 tries for 2x2x3 (one per possible location) (total time is 12 X generations # = 12 X 50'000 = 600'000 generations in our case) 2) 10'000 more generations to enter the 2gen subgroup 3) 200'000 more generations to solve the 2gen group The thing is, (2) and (3) have an open length : if no solution is found after 10'000 generations in step 2, then 10'000 more are searched, and so on. Usually no more than 100'000 (step 2) and 600'000 (step 3) are needed in the extremely tough cases. I guess your 6 hours run was stuck in one of these cases, waiting for "the one" (yes, kind of Matrix-like ...), the magic individual that would solve this phase. Now to the point : is this interesting to develop such a program :) ? Of course you can guess my point of view : first, I slightly disagree when you tell we can find sub-40 solutions within one minute : we would have amazing results in the speed-FMC's, what I did not observe last week ;-) And don't forget that (it's only a personnal estimation) no more than say 1% of all cubers and speedcubers can produce sub-40 moves averages. My program average, calculated on 15 independent runs, is at the moment 34 : just to test I used your scramble and the alg found y D' L2 F' R2 B' F' L2 R D F' D' F L' U L2 F L' U F2 U2 F' U F U' F U F' U2 F' U2 F2 U' F' U F' U2 (36 moves HTM). The aim is not (actually it was once but not I feel more modest ...) to find solutions as good as yours, or Per's or other FMC champions, but to produce relatively short solutions without knowing a single algorithm ! What about the random search ? Well, my program examines about 3000 moves sequences per second. For building a 2x2x3, you need an average of (let's be optimistic) 9-10 moves, that means about 18 X 15^8 > 10^10 sequences, or 925 hours ... and the 2-gen phase would have about the same length ... The good performance of Kociemba's alg and (some) human players is a question of tactics, but also of known algs or caracteristical positions (Kociemba's uses Mo-sized tables) ... I hope I convinced you :) I will try to incorporate some time indications in the program, but at the moment you can have a quite accurate idea if you remember that there are 12x50'000 generations for phase 1, about 10'000 for phase 2 and about 200'000 for the last one. Finally, an easy way to run multiple instances of the prog is to run copies of the .exe file from different folders. One result file per folder will then be created ... I know it's not the ultimate programmer's way but I claim I'm not a computer scientist ;-) Thanks for your comments and your help :) cyril --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s ...> wrote: > > Well, I downloaded your genetic solver, run it on my fast notebook > (it's Pentium something like 1.8 GHz, not sure now) and kept checking > if the program was running. After more than 6 hours I got tired and > canceled the job. I conclude this suggestion: show an estimated total > time the calculations will take. If it's not possible, show some > information about how far the calculations are. It's well possible > that I canceled the job very close to the finish because I had no clue > how far the finish was. > I've been running the program on Pentium 3.4 GHz for 2 hours now. > Whuooooo, it finished and I don't know when. Can't you show the total > time? I could run the program overnight on this PC if you supported > multiple runs. This is what you should do if you want me to run it > more than twice. :-) > Are you sure it's any faster than a random search in each phase? > The resulting 39 moves is what we can often do under one minute. With > a help of your program it takes hours. I know, it's a project on > genetic algorithms ;-). > Mirek > > Result: > Scramble : > U' L U' D' F2 R D B' L R' D L2 D' F' D' R2 F' U2 R' D' F R B2 > L2 R2 D2 B' U' D' F' > whole cube clockwise rotation around Oz (= y) > whole cube rotation around LR horizontal axis (=x) > whole cube rotation around LR horizontal axis (=x) > Solution : > R2 U L U2 B L2 U L U F U2 R > U2 R U' F' L F R' L' > F' U2 F U2 F2 U2 F U2 F2 U' F' U F U' F U' F' U F > total moves # : 39 > > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" > <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > > Hi ! > > > > Actually the title is not a joke, I would greatly appreciate if you > > could help me with my genetic solver project. One solve for a 30- moves > > scramble takes about 3 hours on my computer, and my aim is to test the > > program on 100 random scrambles ... > > So if you are kind enough for helping me, here is what you can do : > > > > 1)Download the 2.1 version of the program : > > http://cyril.webzzanine.net/cube/genetic21.exe > > It's a simple windows executable, virus-free (I swear :) ), about 430 > > ko > > > > 2)Launch the program from your hard drive and enter the following > > parameters : 1 [enter], then 50000 [enter], then 30 [enter] : this > > leads to a 30-moves random scramble, with each 2x2x3 location searched > > for 50000 generations > > > > 3)Once the program is over, you'll see a sentence telling that "the > > cube was solved in XXX moves", meaning that it's done. A new file > > called results.txt should have been created in the same folder as the > > genetic21.exe file. It contains the scramble, and the different phases > > of the solution found. Save it with any other name (since results. txt > > is emptied at the start of each new simulation), and once you have > > some results you can email them to me at cyrilca [at] caramail [dot] > > com > > > > The program does not require a lot of cpu and memory, one is able to > > work normally when it's running... > > > > I feel like the guys in charge of the SETI@Home project, even if the > > goal is here slightly different ! Many thanks to the FMC community for > > helping me in that project ! > > > > cyril > > > > PS : and of course all suggestions are welcome, even if there are lots > > of things I already would like to implement without having time to do > > so ...
313. Speed Cubing :-)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 14:09:45 -0000

Many congratz to Mirek/Gilles :-) Managing 34 pts is absolutely brilliant achievement! I can't see how that it is possible to do it myself. I'm simply too slow making the required decisions :-( When i heard about Sebastian doing 35 pts last week i was sure he was gonna take the UWR. I was wrong. I found the scramble last week worse to deal with than the scramble the week before. So i guess i just tried all the wrong stuff first... Once again very well done Mirek/Gilles :D Now it's slow solving this week so i will definitely find something good ;-) Cheers! -Per
314. Re: Speed Cubing :-)
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 09 Jul 2005 17:47:16 -0000

In my case it's a matter of luck. My average without taking moves back is still likely above 40 in about 4 minutes for each attempt. Here we have the advantage of taking moves back, but time's running fast as you know. Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Many congratz to Mirek/Gilles :-) > > Managing 34 pts is absolutely brilliant achievement! 315. My late 24-move entry
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 15 Jul 2005 13:39:30 -0000

Hi, I found a nice 8-move F U2 F L B2 F' L' R2 for 2x2x3 block. It needed a modification that allowed me to get 2 layers in 15 moves: F U2 F R D2 L _ F R' F2 R2 L' B' U2 B2 U', 2 layers, R D. B D' B' R' B' and insert 3-corner cycle at the dot as D' R' U R D R' U' R. This is what I would have posted if I had not burried and missed the first 15 moves in my notes. F U2 F R D2 L F R' F2 R2 L' B' U2 B2 R D R' U' R B D' B' R' B' (24,30) Mirek
316. Per, your f2l in 13 moves is amazing!
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 15 Jul 2005 17:00:53 -0000

It's unbelievable, I like it very much. It's a pity you have missed a better insertion then: R' B2 R F' R' B2 R F right after the fifth move R' F' B L R. That would be 26 HTM. Mirek
317. Re: Per, your f2l in 13 moves is amazing!
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 12:02:21 -0000

Well, This is last time i will forget to finalise my solution until 30 mins before deadline :-P The pressure of getting it done in time made me miss the best insertion *shrugs* The way i work now is to first come up with a few good starts which i leave for finalisation later. I use my "cube-math" skills to judge what is a good start. Finding a good start is most often the hard work so i leave finishing them off for later sometimes, instead of having all the fun there and then ;-) Yes that 13 move f2l was really cool. It's not the best i ever found, or that others found for that matter. I recall u Mirek had a 12-move f2l once. I also think i have found 12 before. Not sure if that start made it into the final solution at that time though. A shame u missed the deadline Mirek. Great solution also with a splendid insertion to finish it off. My best ever insertion for corner 3-cycle was cancelling 7 moves. Umm .. apart from "move-shift" insertions which were not really productive for a real solution purpose. But i have used that to yield "solution" with a few twisted corners only :-) Ok, bring the next scramble. I won't "forget" the deadline this time :- P Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s...> wrote: > It's unbelievable, I like it very much. > It's a pity you have missed a better insertion then: R' B2 R F' R' B2 > R F right after the fifth move R' F' B L R. That would be 26 HTM. > Mirek

319. FMC #93 Scramble
From: <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Sat, 16 Jul 2005 22:55:50 +0100

Hi everyone, I'm an idiot, I forgot to update the scramble before I went away to Stroud for the UK puzzle meeting, which by the way went very well! The scramble for FMC #93 is: F2 B U' L (R2 U' F' D')*4 U' B2 R L2 (D' F2 B L2)*4 U2 L R F I shall update the website as soon as I get home. Sorry about this! Hope that everyone gets the message, pass it on :) Dan :) ----------------------------------------- Email provided by http://www.ntlhome.com/

323. Am I blind ?
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 2005 08:12:29 -0000

Hey there, My submission rythm is a bit chaotic these times -it seems that when I'm on holiday it's a bit more complicated to find motivation ;-) Anyway I'm looking forward to see your solutions for this week's challenge ! I especially wonder if someone found something to do with the "evident" magic 7 moves 2x2x3 block (or call it an unsanely easy extended cross if you're fridrichian ...) I spent hours trying to get something out of it but got stuck and finally abandoned :-( Good luck for next week, I won't be able to participate but I'll be back in two weeks ! cyril
324. Team FMC will soon be launched! - Here are the teams
From: "Daniel Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 2005 17:56:45 +0100

HI everyone! As you know, the special celebration to mark 100 Fewest Moves Competitions, will be a special team event. Each team of 3 will be given 5 weeks to come up with the best solution to the cube. You can submit as many solutions as you like, but you will only be ranked on the solution with the lowest number of turns, averaged over all 4 turning metrics. I will post all the solutions, so if you want to come up with some fun and crazy solutions too, then feel free! The teams (at the moment) currently stand as: Per Kristen Fredlund (C), Bob Burton, Sachin [surname not supplied] Mirek Goljan (C), Chris Hardwick, Alexander Ooms Sebastian Dumitrescu (C), Mikael Nyberg, Ravi Fernando Lars Petrus (C), Gilles Roux, Cyril Castella Charles Tsai (C), Francois Sechet, Parker Gaitley. Please come up with some decent team names before the launch of the scramble, and let me know ;) Jason Kovacic is currently looking for 2 team members to join him, can you help? Email me at danh@... if you want to participate with Jason. I will also stand in if necessary, but be warned, I'm not very good ;) Shortly you will receive contact details for your team members, so try to establish some sort of contact before the launch of the scramble, which all being well, will be in 3 weeks time. Eventually all the things you need to know will find their way onto this page: http://www.necrophagous.co.uk/cubestation/fmcresults/teamfmc100.php - so check it out! Good Luck everyone! Dan :)
325. Re: Am I blind ? - also answer to Per
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 29 Jul 2005 20:54:30 -0000

Hi, I'm puzzled which 7 moves you mean. I don't remember any evident 7 moves for 2x2x3. After I submitted my solution first week I found the same as Per [L'] D' L2 F2 R' D2 L, the first move is realized before scrambling and thus at the end of a solution, Per calls it "premove". I count it together as 7-move 2x2x3. I spend a lot of time with this start without any good finish. The best was 2 twisted corners after 22 moves. Congrats Per! Doing edges first with 3 or more corners seems to be the most efficient method, now. Bad for others, Per, you're the only one who currently masters it. Interestingly, edges first is one of the worst methods for speedcubing! Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > Hey there, > My submission rythm is a bit chaotic these times -it seems that when > I'm on holiday it's a bit more complicated to find motivation ;-) > Anyway I'm looking forward to see your solutions for this week's > challenge ! I especially wonder if someone found something to do with > the "evident" magic 7 moves 2x2x3 block (or call it an unsanely easy > extended cross if you're fridrichian ...) I spent hours trying to get > something out of it but got stuck and finally abandoned :-( > Good luck for next week, I won't be able to participate but I'll be > back in two weeks ! > > cyril
326. Re: Am I blind ? - also answer to Per
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 01:13:37 -0000

Hi! Yes, indeed its the same 7-move start as Cyril struggled with. If i do the premove to the scramble it's 2x2x3 in 6 moves. Otherwise it's simply 7 moves, yes :-) The point doing the premove to the scramble though is that ur life is a whole lot easier when seeing how to do the rest after the otherwise pseudo block :-) I wouldn't say i master that technique of all edges and 3 or more corners really. Some weeks i struggle and don't find them. Usually need at least a couple of hrs with trial and error cause the edges end up wrong ... lol ... Well it's fun when i get it to work. I often also find bad cases with several twisted corners or too many unsolved. That is kinda ok if i get 1 twisted corner and a 3-cycle. Or the rather rare 2 pure corner 3-cycles (6 unsolved corners). It's more or less eqvivalent to finding 4 corners which is 2 2- cycles. It's a bit more strict with that twisted corner cause i need to "bring it out of its twistedness" and into a 3-cycle. How i do that is to use 5 stickers. I do like for normal pure 3-cycle put on stickers numbered 1,2 and 3. Now i add another sticker on the cubie with 1 already on it. This is because the sticker 3 can move to this sticker now numbered 4. The last sticker i label for instance _*_ or simply 5 and put on the twisted corner. Now my first insertion must do one of following : (1,2,[5]),(2,3,[5]) or (3,4,[5]) meaning i just use the cubie with 5 on it, orientation of this cubie won't matter. Please note that (3,1,[5]) will be really wrong. This just gives me a new case with 3-cycle and a twisted corner again :-( Now i have a normal 3-cycle that i deal with the usual way :-) Ummm ... i hope this helps some at least :D Also, as mentioned before it's worth trying to try solve 2 or 3 twisted corners as a series of 2 pure 3-cycles if the start is otherwise good :-) I leave it to urselves to work out how. It's not hard at all in principle :-) But many combinations to consider ... Have fun! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s...> wrote: > Hi, > I'm puzzled which 7 moves you mean. I don't remember any evident 7 > moves for 2x2x3. After I submitted my solution first week I found the > same as Per [L'] D' L2 F2 R' D2 L, the first move is realized before > scrambling and thus at the end of a solution, Per calls it "premove". > I count it together as 7-move 2x2x3. I spend a lot of time with this > start without any good finish. The best was 2 twisted corners after 22 > moves. > Congrats Per! Doing edges first with 3 or more corners seems to be the > most efficient method, now. Bad for others, Per, you're the only one > who currently masters it. > Interestingly, edges first is one of the worst methods for speedcubing! > Mirek > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" > <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > > Hey there, > > My submission rythm is a bit chaotic these times -it seems that when > > I'm on holiday it's a bit more complicated to find motivation ;- ) > > Anyway I'm looking forward to see your solutions for this week's > > challenge ! I especially wonder if someone found something to do with > > the "evident" magic 7 moves 2x2x3 block (or call it an unsanely easy > > extended cross if you're fridrichian ...) I spent hours trying to get > > something out of it but got stuck and finally abandoned :-( > > Good luck for next week, I won't be able to participate but I'll be > > back in two weeks ! > > > > cyril
327. Re: Am I blind ? - also answer to Per
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 04:12:54 -0000

Exactly, the same game with corners I play if I solve edges in a short enough way. The sticker I put on twisted corners has no number - this is the only (negligable) difference. It's maybe worth to say how I found the 7-moves. I didn't see them easily. First, the premove can be recognized as a move that puts few pieces on their final correct place but you don't want to make that move because it pushes solved pieces apart. OK, look at scramble #93 and then the same scramble with additional move L' at the beginning. Now, L2 F2 R' D2 solves a 2x2x2 part. I try to insert one move that does not make an effect on the 2x2x2 and then see if there is any advantage of doing it or not. Here I tried D, D2, and D' before L2 F2 R' D2. Sure, D' wins. Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hi! > > Yes, indeed its the same 7-move start as Cyril struggled with. 328. Re: Am I blind ? - also answer to Per
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 04:50:56 -0000

Hi Mirek :-) Very nice insertions at the end ur solution :-) I haven't got round to check the "no-insertion" scenario yet. Maybe i do so tomorrow. Indeed using so long cycles u need a rather huge overlap for it to pay off versus inserting 8 moves w no cancellation. I'm still to see a scenario were inserting 8 move 3-cycle wasn't possible, even with no cancellation ;-) My best ever 5-cycle insertion was 7 moves. One 7-move cancellation. And one 2-move cancellation. It takes damn luck to do better than that ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s...> wrote: > Exactly, the same game with corners I play if I solve edges in a > short enough way. I spend a lot of time with > > this > > > start without any good finish. The best was 2 twisted corners > > after 22 > > > moves. > > > Congrats Per! Doing edges first with 3 or more corners seems to > be > > the > > > most efficient method, now. Bad for others, Per, you're the only > > one > > > who currently masters it. > > > Interestingly, edges first is one of the worst methods for > > speedcubing! > > > Mirek > > > > > > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" > > > <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > > > > Hey there, > > > > My submission rythm is a bit chaotic these times -it seems > that > > when > > > > I'm on holiday it's a bit more complicated to find > motivation ;- > > ) > > > > Anyway I'm looking forward to see your solutions for this > week's > > > > challenge ! I especially wonder if someone found something to > do > > with > > > > the "evident" magic 7 moves 2x2x3 block (or call it an > unsanely > > easy > > > > extended cross if you're fridrichian ...) I spent hours trying > > to get > > > > something out of it but got stuck and finally abandoned :-( > > > > Good luck for next week, I won't be able to participate but > I'll > > be > > > > back in two weeks ! > > > > > > > > cyril

330. Mireks _no-insertion_ ending :-o
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 30 Jul 2005 22:27:54 -0000

Hi Mirek :-) After ur 21 moves with one corner insertion done there is at least one insertion cancelling out 1 move, almost right at the end ;-) D2 R' B' D' L' B2 R2 B' L' F2 L2 R' D L' D' R D' F2 D' L'.R2 Simply insert L2 D R D' L2 D R' D' at the dot gives D2 R' B' D' L' B2 R2 B' L' F2 L2 R' D L' D' R D' F2 D' L D R D' L2 D R' D' R2 for a 28 move solution. So, yes the inserted 12-move 3-cycle was better. But ur claim was not correct. Oh well, i missed a 26-move solution week before ... hehe ... Cube blindness :D Interesting :-) Cheers! -Per PS! Actually it's good u didn't find that one. U might have been happy with that. Or maybe not, since it wasn't expert solution :D
331. Re: Mireks _no-insertion_ ending :-o
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 31 Jul 2005 01:37:14 -0000

Thank you for noticing! What is still true that this was a very rare case when 12-move 3-cycle worked best. I feel that in the way I search for insertions there is some room for overlooks. Do you think you can write a set of rules that tell how to do this search quickly with little thinking and no mistakes? Happy cubing! Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Hi Mirek :-) > > After ur 21 moves with one corner insertion done there is at least > one insertion cancelling out 1 move, almost right at the end ;-) > > D2 R' B' D' L' B2 R2 B' L' F2 L2 R' D L' D' R D' F2 D' L'.R2 > > Simply insert L2 D R D' L2 D R' D' at the dot gives D2 R' B' D' L' > B2 R2 B' L' F2 L2 R' D L' D' R D' F2 D' L D R D' L2 D R' D' R2 for a > 28 move solution. 333. New kind of 2-generator challenge
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 01 Aug 2005 12:37:42 -0000

I wanted to submit this idea for a FMC to come, but I think it may be a bit difficult. You already know famous 2-generators like <R,U>. But can you solve in <r,U> ? (r=R+slice). On a solved cube, do a random sequence like (r2UrU2r'...) and tell me if you can find :-) Gilles.

335. Re: Mireks _no-insertion_ ending :-o
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 03 Aug 2005 11:28:42 -0000

Hmmm ... Set of rules? I think u know the insertion game just as well as i do. How good insertions we manage to get is determined by and large by the sequence we have found before beginning the insertions. Well it's true that i normally stop searching for finding better insertion when i have already found best first insertion and then best second insertions (for scenarios which require 2 insertions). There is no guarantee this is the best overall insertion though. I normally have spent so much time finding the first sequence so that i don't have time to consider all possible combinations and find global best overall insertion(s). But really i think u mean a set of rules for finding best single insertion including longer cycles then the basic 8-move ones. I think that's a really hard problem. And theoretically even longer cycles then 12 moves might be best insertion? I don't have any easy proof that that couldn't be the case in some circumstances... One can only prove that the probability is really poor for that longer cycles than 12 moves (or even 10) will give the lowest length solution due to a very high number of cancelled moves. Umm i can take this one step further. If a very long corner 3-cycle is simply a conjugate of a shorter corner 3-cycle it can never be a better insertion than the shorter one contained in it. I think u Mirek has sorta proved this in the past. So the longer ones can't be conjugates at least. They must be long atomic 3-cycles so to speak. Another interesting issue is if all corner 3-cycles must be commutators? I guess that must be the case. All that i have seen are. Or at least a cyclical shift of one (which can be proven to still be commutator). The cyclically shifted one might not follow the isolation principle however. Which means that that one part P (or Q) in the PQP'Q' pattern won't necessarily change only 1 corner in some layer. Hmm... This got very technical towards the end. Maybe some enjoy reading it ;-) Have fun! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s...> wrote: > Thank you for noticing! What is still true that this was a very rare > case when 12-move 3-cycle worked best. > I feel that in the way I search for insertions there is some room > for overlooks. Do you think you can write a set of rules that tell > how to do this search quickly with little thinking and no mistakes? > Happy cubing! > Mirek > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi Mirek :-) > > > > After ur 21 moves with one corner insertion done there is at least > > one insertion cancelling out 1 move, almost right at the end ;-) > > > > D2 R' B' D' L' B2 R2 B' L' F2 L2 R' D L' D' R D' F2 D' L'.R2 > > > > Simply insert L2 D R D' L2 D R' D' at the dot gives D2 R' B' D' L' > > B2 R2 B' L' F2 L2 R' D L' D' R D' F2 D' L D R D' L2 D R' D' R2 for > a > > 28 move solution. So, yes the inserted 12-move 3-cycle was better. > > But ur claim was not correct. Oh well, i missed a 26-move solution > > week before ... hehe ... Cube blindness :D > > > > Interesting :-) > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per > > > > PS! Actually it's good u didn't find that one. U might have been > > happy with that. Or maybe not, since it wasn't expert solution :D
336. Re: New kind of 2-generator challenge
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Aug 2005 07:57:23 -0000

> I tried it the first time you posted it and i tried it again this > time but I still don't know how to do it. Oh, I already posted the idea? I couldn't remember, sorry for repeating! > So how do you do it Gilles??? You know, right? Wrong, I don't know, that's why I'm asking :-) Knowing how it works could be interesting for speedcubing (and 1-handed cubing). It looks so easy, only 2 kinf of turns, r and U... But after 5 moves or so I'm completely lost. I thought maybe FMC competitors could find some interesting properties and theorems. But managing corners and edges at the same time has never been easy. And there's something worse here, r and U do not have the same (symetrical) effects on edges. Gilles.
337. Re: New kind of 2-generator challenge
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 04 Aug 2005 09:33:11 -0000

I found a three-corner-orienter yesterday that I can do in 12 seconds but it may not be interesting for FMC :-) (r U' r' U' r U r' U')*10 After F2L, this could orient U corners by applying it once or twice, and they're permuted correctly (at least relative to each other) anyway, like in <U,R>. I think Gilles also mentioned it to me in email a while ago and I found a way to solve the cube in 5 minutes or so, but I forgot ;-) Cheers! Stefan --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f. ..> wrote: > > I tried it the first time you posted it and i tried it again this > > time but I still don't know how to do it. > > Oh, I already posted the idea? I couldn't remember, sorry for repeating! > > > > So how do you do it Gilles??? You know, right? > > Wrong, I don't know, that's why I'm asking :-) > Knowing how it works could be interesting for speedcubing (and 1-handed > cubing). > > It looks so easy, only 2 kinf of turns, r and U... But after 5 moves or > so I'm completely lost. I thought maybe FMC competitors could find some > interesting properties and theorems. > > But managing corners and edges at the same time has never been easy. > And there's something worse here, r and U do not have the same > (symetrical) effects on edges. > > Gilles.

339. Re: Am I blind ? - back to #93
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 08 Aug 2005 07:56:44 -0000

Hi, I was on holiday this week ... many interesting posts to read ... I just wanted to mention the 2x2x3 block I was speaking about in my last post : I did not want to give the moves at that time since the challenge was not closed, but it's not the same as you mention : Scramble was : F2 B U' L (R2 U' F' D')*4 U' B2 R L2 (D' F2 B L2)*4 U2 L R F (without premove) 2x2x3 in 7 moves : B'L'BF2D2F'L' it's quite self-explaining : while building the 2x2x2, the first 2 moves connect the other Corner-Edge pair. So instead of finising the 2x2x2, just put the 2 CE pairs in the same layer and build the 2x2x3 as two 2x3x1 blocks :-) I noticed that for us it's very often much easier to find 2x2x3 blocks as 2x2x2 + 2x2x1 ... This leaves 6 bad oriented edges that one could fix either with F2UD'F'U'D2RD' (getting into 2-gen group in 15 moves) or with D'UF'DU2R'U (2x2x3 + orientation of the edges in 14 moves), for example. I then tried to form some 2x2x1 blocks but did not manage to find any good ending. I think after the 7 moves I should have tried to mix the orientation of the bad edges with the building of such blocks, but I'm not an expert with that approach ... Good luck to you if you want to use this week's break to play with that idea ;-) cyril --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" <goljan@s. ..> wrote: > Hi, > I'm puzzled which 7 moves you mean. I don't remember any evident 7 > moves for 2x2x3. After I submitted my solution first week I found the same as Per [L'] D' L2 F2 R' D2 L, the first move is realized before scrambling and thus at the end of a solution, Per calls it "premove". > I count it together as 7-move 2x2x3. I spend a lot of time with this > start without any good finish. The best was 2 twisted corners after 22 moves.
340. Re: New kind of 2-generator challenge
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 10 Aug 2005 14:16:57 -0000

Hi ! I had a go at Gilles' idea ... damn it feels insane ! I tried some tricks with Charles' FMC companion and here is what I found : (r U' r' U)*3 (r U r' U')*3 (let's call it C5) is a corner 5-cyle : all corners move except BDR. 24 moves. And should be quite fast to execute ... Interesting are the variations one can make, like (C5 U2)*2, which twists the same corners without affecting their position. 50 moves, let's call it T5. ... then the combination with stefan's alg T3 : (((r U' r' U)*3 (r U r' U')*3) U2)*4 ((r U' r' U' r U r' U')*10 U2)*2 , or (C5 U2)*4 (T3 U2)*2 , or T5*2 (T3 U2)*2 which twists 2 corners, that's all ! This one may be interesting ... don't forget it next time you find 2 twisted corners after a nice FMC start : more than 250 moves, but being slightly lucky one can honestly hope cancelling a few dozens ;-) Actually I wonder if these algs + eventually another corner 3-cycle would be sufficient to solve the cube. I would imply solve all edges first, then the corners ... OK, that was my contribution ... I gotta work now :-) cyril --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > I found a three-corner-orienter yesterday that I can do in 12 seconds but it may not be interesting for FMC :-) > (r U' r' U' r U r' U')*10
341. Re: New kind of 2-generator challenge
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 11 Aug 2005 07:49:33 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > [...] > or (C5 U2)*4 (T3 U2)*2 , or T5*2 (T3 U2)*2 which twists 2 corners, > that's all ! This one may be interesting ... don't forget it next time > you find 2 twisted corners after a nice FMC start : more than 250 > moves, but being slightly lucky one can honestly hope cancelling a few > dozens ;-) We'll think about it :-) More strange or unefficient sequences: - (rUr2U)6 - permutation that do not change corners - (r2U2)6 - permutation that do not change corners - rUr'UrU2r'U'r'U'rU'r'U2rU - it's only two symetrical "r-Sune"s - (rUrUr'Ur'U)4 - (r2Ur2U'rUr') (U*) (r2Ur2U'rUr') (U*)' - a "LL" commutator - rU'r2Ur2Ur2U'r -- LL too - And the magical (rUr'U')6 of course :-) Gilles.

343. Display of our FMC solutions : a suggestion
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 12 Aug 2005 13:19:36 -0000

Hi, While having a look at some past FMC results, I had an idea (Dan, don't be afraid, it would not take you much more time I think ...) A lot of us [well ... except you Gilles, who never act like the others when cubing :) ] find first the "skeleton" of the solution, a short sequence with some edges and/or corners out of place or flipped, and then fix them with corners- or edges-cycles inserted at good places. I don't know if you take a real cube to have a look at these skeletons, but personnaly I don't since the probability I would mess up in the scramble or in the solution is a bit too high :) ... and I think the cube applet is a really good way to present the full solutions. The idea would be to add another optional field in the submission page called "basis" or "skeleton" or whatever, that you Dan could use for displaying another applet next to the one giving the solution. I think it could be really interesting to learn from Per the magic of edges- first solving, or to see the blocks built by other competitors ... What do you think about it ? Can't wait for the special #100 scramble :) cyril

Lists of teams have been sent out already, so you should all know who you are with, and have made contact with them. Any problems, please let me know by sending a mail to teamfmc@... 347. New Rubik's Cube Software
From: "pyjamamitten" <jpittman@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 19 Aug 2005 17:28:18 -0000

Greetings cube fans, We are working on some 3D puzzle software that should be of interest to this group in particular. Please drop over to http://www.gabbasoft.com and head to the downloads section (excuse the mess, the site is being re-designed). The demo app only supports cube-shaped puzzles but we are implementing other shapes and puzzle styles into the finished product. We would appreciate your feedback on the product. The demo is for PC only and requires DirectX9.0b or greater to run. Use the left mouse button to turn a face on the cube and the right mouse button to rotate your view of the cube. Regards, Jamey Pittman President GabbaSoft, Inc. http://www.gabbasoft.com
348. Re: New Rubik's Cube Software

For those who can't wait for the 6x6x6 olympicube it's well worth checking out. Maybe i should speak to those guys about implementing super-supercubing. 351. Re: Team FMC has been launched
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 15:16:43 -0000

3-cycle insertions would be quite difficult :-) You inspired Cyril, he created a thread on our private forum, hehe, and we started to build a solution, 4 moves per turn, and you don't know what others have in mind. Every team could try it, as a bonus for FMC#100. Gilles. --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Umm Gilles ... > > Did u do that like u do team speedsolving? Take turn making one move > each? Then 52 might be hard to beat ... lol ... :-P > > Have fun :-) > > -Per > > >--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" > <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Daniel Harris" > > <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > > Hi everyone! > > > > > > > > > > > > The Team FMC is ready to go! > > > [...] > > > > > > > Our team has already started to think, and guess what, we've already > > found a solution! 52 moves. Try to beat us! > > > > Gilles.
352. Re: Team FMC has been launched
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 22 Aug 2005 22:47:56 -0000

Just in case you are interested, here are the rules of our team for what I called the ultimate blindfolded-like team solve : of course, you can adapt them in your team ... Our solution is growing, it's really funny to see the complementarity :) cyril - each of us can add up to 4 moves to the current partial solution. Gilles, your slice moves count as one move - one can propose moves that undo one or more moves - when one has added some moves to the partial solution, any other team member can continue (otherwise it might be a bit long ...) - one can add premoves (or setup moves) before the scramble. This counts as one move. - I claim we can use FMC companion here : http://www.necrophagous.co. uk/cubestation/fmcresults/teamfmccomp2_1/fmccomp.php to avoid too much scrambling ... - of course, no constructive comment about the added moves is allowed :) --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f ...> wrote: > > 3-cycle insertions would be quite difficult :-) > > You inspired Cyril, he created a thread on our private forum, hehe, > and we started to build a solution, 4 moves per turn, and you don't > know what others have in mind. > > Every team could try it, as a bonus for FMC#100. > > > Gilles. >
353. Re: Team FMC has been launched
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 23 Aug 2005 19:49:51 -0000

Hi! I think the point about no constructive comments defeats the object of what u try to achieve ;-) Fewest moves is different from speedsolving. Doing a few moves there u could hope the other will recognize which case u are doing according to how far u are in the solution (well-defined steps). But hey, you can change that later. It's easier to follow up moves if u know the idea/plan behind the previous moves made. I can of coz understand why u wanted that rule also. Not to restrict urselves too much :-) Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > Just in case you are interested, here are the rules of our team for > what I called the ultimate blindfolded-like team solve : of course, > you can adapt them in your team ... Our solution is growing, it's > really funny to see the complementarity :) > > cyril > > > - each of us can add up to 4 moves to the current partial solution. > Gilles, your slice moves count as one move > - one can propose moves that undo one or more moves > - when one has added some moves to the partial solution, any other > team member can continue (otherwise it might be a bit long ...) > - one can add premoves (or setup moves) before the scramble. This > counts as one move. > - I claim we can use FMC companion here : http://www.necrophagous.co. > uk/cubestation/fmcresults/teamfmccomp2_1/fmccomp.php to avoid too much > scrambling ... > - of course, no constructive comment about the added moves is allowed > :) > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f > ...> wrote: > > > > 3-cycle insertions would be quite difficult :-) > > > > You inspired Cyril, he created a thread on our private forum, hehe, > > and we started to build a solution, 4 moves per turn, and you don't > > know what others have in mind. > > > > Every team could try it, as a bonus for FMC#100. > > > > > > Gilles. > >
354. New Cube Demo With Input Method Change + Help Screen
From: "pyjamamitten" <jpittman@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 25 Aug 2005 15:09:28 -0000

Greetings, We want to thank everyone from the online cubing community who has been kind enough to send us their comments, ideas, and suggestions. Over the past week, we have accumulated some great ideas from you folks as to how we can make our product better! Please keep sending us feedback and continue to try out the new versions as we post them. The biggest change in the new version is related to the comments we've received about wanting an alternate method of orienting your view of the cube. So, without losing the existing freedom of rotation, we have added a secondary way to change your view of the cube. Holding down the left shift key while rotating a slice of the cube will turn the *entire* cube 90 degrees (or 180 if you also have the left CTRL key down) in the same axis/direction the single slice would have moved. This eases the ability to 'flip' the cube around and see the backside without losing your current perspective on the cube. Thanks to Jol van Noort for this suggestion! An in-game help screen has been added that details all the available controls as well. The change log for the demo project is now posted on the downloads page of our website (http://www.gabbasoft.com) if anyone is interested in seeing everything that has been modified to date. Again, thanks so much for all of your input and we hope you will continue to send us your thoughts and ideas for making our product better. Regards, Jamey Pittman President GabbaSoft, Inc. jpittman@... http://www.gabbasoft.com
355. Cube Demo Updated For 20x20x20 Cube Support
From: "pyjamamitten" <jpittman@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 27 Aug 2005 03:37:41 -0000

Greetings, I can't believe how many requests we've received about the desire for larger cubes! Of course, I should have known better after I saw that someone in Japan had solved the 9x9x9 in a little over 2 hours and posted the screenshots on his site. So, as of this release, we now support cube sizes up to 20x20x20. I would certainly expect that performance will noticably degrade on slower/older systems when you get up to 15x15x15 and above but you are free to give `em a try. Ton from Speedcubing.com made the request for changing the timer behavior to wait until the first move is made after a scramble to start seemed to be a good idea to me so that has been added as well. We've also received enough comments about the moving background making people dizzy to change it and make it static we hope you like it better! You can get the latest version from our downloads page: http://www.gabbasoft.com/download.htm As always, thanks so much for all of your input and we hope you will continue to send us your thoughts and ideas for making our product better. Regards, Jamey Pittman President GabbaSoft, Inc. jpittman@... http://www.gabbasoft.com

358. Re: What is valid for FMC #97?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 29 Aug 2005 16:00:27 -0000

Ummmm ... No wonder i didn't notice since i didn't participate last week. Ok i might as well submit my beautiful solution here to this forum then. Dan, are u gonna put up the correct scramble? Aaaahhh ... Got it! If u open the link to the FMC companion u will see the correct scramble is given there. Ok, back to the workbench for cracking the REAL fmc #97. LOL :D #97 scramble = U' D (L B2 D' L2 F)*4 B' U' R2 B F' (R' U B2 U2 L)*4 B R ====== SOLUTION FMC #96 (late entry) Moves: F U' R' D F' B' R B L' R F R' B' R F' R2 B2 U B2 U D' L' D' Explanation: First i found the following 13 moves leaving 5 corners to be solved : F U' R' D F' L'.B U B2 U D' L' D' Now i inserted L B' R B L' B':R' B at the dot and B R F R' B' R F' R' at the colon. That's all there is to it. Only problem is to find the start. That takes 90% of the time :-( Too bad this is not the fmc#97 solution. LOL :D ====== Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "c_w_tsai" <c_w_tsai@y...> wrote: > Then you missed out since that was the scramble for #96 :P > > Click on the fmc comp link (in the submission form) and you'll see > the scramble that matches the picture > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hey Mirek!! > > > > I really hope that the given scramble there is correct and not the > > picture. Cause i already found a really nice solution with edges > first > > and 5 corner finish ;-) > > > > IM not sure what went wrong though :-o > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" > > <goljan@s...> wrote: > > > Dan, is it the scrambling algorithm or the picture of the > scrambled > > > cube on > > http://www.necrophagous.co.uk/cubestation/fmcresults/fmc.php ? > > > Am I dumb or they don't match? > > > Mirek

Date: Thu, 01 Sep 2005 04:09:15 -0000

Greetings, Our newest cube demo (ver 0.03.0007) includes (among other changes) supercube versions for every puzzle size! It is available now on our website (http://www.gabbasoft.com). Although not originally something we had considered doing, you online cubers have been so wonderful about sharing your ideas and comments with us that we wanted to make something just for you: the only folks we know that might not cry at the thought of solving a 20x20x20 supercube. We also increased the range of the timer and move counters to accomodate the larger cube sizes. So enjoy and keep the suggestions coming!! 362. What is lucky, and when is it allowed ?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 16:24:27 -0000

Hi guys !! Since it's creating so much havoc to have luck in a short solution im now retiring from FMC. I am spending hours and hours each week working on block starts and edge-first starts. I sometimes produce more than 10 different edges- first starts before i get useful corners so that i can carry on with insertions. Over the last 20 or so normal FMC's i have produced maybe closer to 200 edges-first starts. The chance of getting a "lucky" corner after having 3 corners is 1/6*1/3 (position and orientation repectively). Working on all those starts of mine one or more lucky corners are bound to happen. And yes i agree it might seem like magic. But im ditching closer to 95% of my edges-first starts due to bad corners. When i can't find a useful edges-first start i go for the slightly worse 2x2x3 block start which is a lot easier to find. And this produces on average a 2 moves longer solution. Both of those starts let me do corner insertions in the end which is my favorite way of fewest moves. And it should be proven already it's one of the best ways also. As explained to Dan there is no way i can explain that sometimes i get 2 "lucky" corners. But to carry on reasoning the odds is not that bad : 1/(18*15). So ok it's happened twice i got 2 "lucky" corners. This should have taken me 540 solves and i have achieved it after 200 solves. I don't think that's a crime. Take care everyone :-) -Per
363. Re: What is lucky, and when is it allowed ?
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 17:03:44 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > [...] > have taken me 540 solves and i have achieved it > after 200 solves. I don't think that's a crime. If trying hundreds of solves hoping to be lucky is a crime, I shouldn't go back home tonight. Gunmen, tanks and helicopters must be waiting for me. Gilles.
364. Re: What is lucky, and when is it allowed ?
From: "Mike G" <m.godfrey@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 06 Sep 2005 17:23:06 -0000

Sorry, I am a non-combatant here, but I want to comment anyway... --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Since it's creating so much havoc to have luck in a short solution > im now retiring from FMC. Sounds like hard work to me, not luck. > the odds is not > that bad : 1/(18*15). So ok it's happened twice i got 2 "lucky" > corners. This should have taken me 540 solves and i have achieved it > after 200 solves. I don't think that's a crime. Assuming the attempts are independent (not obvious, since you make ~10 on each cube), the probability of /not/ getting 2 lucky corners on a given cube is q = (1 - 1/(15*18))^10 = 0.9636 Probability of never getting 2 lucky corners in 20 cubes is q^20 = 0.476 Probability of getting 2 lucky corners exactly once in 20 cubes is 20*(1-q)*q^19 = 0.360 Probability of it happening twice /or more/ times = 0.164 So what happened is about as lucky as getting a "six" in a single throw of a die. No big deal. Mike
365. Re: What is lucky, and when is it allowed ?
From: "Mike G" <m.godfrey@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 10:06:55 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Mike G" <m.godfrey@m...> wrote: > So what happened is about as lucky as getting a "six" in a single > throw of a die. No big deal. [That was assuming that the "luckily" solved corners have to be a particular pair -- the probability will be considerably higher if it can be any pair.] As for being left with a 3-cycle after solving edges and (intentionally) solving 2 corners -- is that the "disputed" case? -- there are 2*binomial(6,3)=40 ways for this to happen out of 6!/2 = 360 permutations. Taking into acount the orientations as well, the probability of it happening on one attempt is (40/360)*(1/3)^6 = 1/6561, corresponding to about a 3% chance of it happening once in 200 trials. Again, it's not outrageously improbable... and the chances could be much higher if you are keeping an eye on those 6 corners as you solve the first two. Mike
366. Re: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: What is lucky, and when is it allowed ?
From: <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Wed, 7 Sep 2005 12:17:10 +0100

Hi, As much as i like to see the talk about probabilities, its not the real issue here. I asked Per as nicely as possible to shed some more light on his 14 move start, which is standard practice for solutions as short as that one, if anything so that other people can appreciate why the person went the way he/she did. Per,in my opinion completely overreacted when asked this, refused to explain and share his secret, got very defensive and "retired" from FMC. How am I expected to respond? I hope Per, that you will contiue to work with your team for thebenefit of the special teamfmc100 event. Dan :) > > From: "Mike G" <m.godfrey@...> > Date: 2005/09/07 Wed AM 11:06:55 BST > To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com > Subject: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: What is lucky, and when is it allowed ? > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Mike G" <m.godfrey@m...> > wrote: > > So what happened is about as lucky as getting a "six" in a single > > throw of a die. No big deal. > > [That was assuming that the "luckily" solved corners have to be a > particular pair -- the probability will be considerably higher if it > can be any pair.] > > As for being left with a 3-cycle after solving edges and > (intentionally) solving 2 corners -- is that the "disputed" case? -- > there are 2*binomial(6,3)=40 ways for this to happen out of 6!/2 = 360 > permutations. Taking into acount the orientations as well, the > probability of it happening on one attempt is (40/360)*(1/3)^6 = > 1/6561, corresponding to about a 3% chance of it happening once in 200 > trials. Again, it's not outrageously improbable... and the chances > could be much higher if you are keeping an eye on those 6 corners as > you solve the first two. > > Mike > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > ----------------------------------------- Email sent from www.ntlworld.com Virus-checked using McAfee(R) Software Visit www.ntlworld.com/security for more information
367. Re: What is lucky, and when is it allowed ?
From: "Mike G" <m.godfrey@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 07 Sep 2005 12:35:18 -0000

Sorry, Dan -- I didn't realize that the issue was the short "start". Although it's remarkable that 14 turns is optimal for solving everything except the corners DLB/UFR/UBL, it presumably is not optimal for solving edges and 2 corners. It would certainly be fun to know how the reasoning works, if this kind of thing can actually be analysed. But it might be rather like asking a gymnast /exactly/ how a backwards somersault is executed, in the hope that a verbal description will make it easier to do it oneself. ;) Mike --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > As much as i like to see the talk about probabilities, [The discussion was wrong anyway -- too many factors of (1/3)... the estimated probability for success on one trial should be 27 times bigger.]

372. Re: scramble for #99
From: "Mike G" <m.godfrey@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 18 Sep 2005 14:45:30 -0000

Just idle curiosity, but why are FMC scrambles traditionally created by hand? I can understand why you mightn't want a near-optimal generator produced by Cube Explorer (too depressing!), but why not a 25-turn computer-generated scramble? Mike --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "c_w_tsai" <c_w_tsai@y...> wrote: > Hi Dan, > > This part of the scramble: (B D' R2 D B' )*3 > isn't very effective :) > > ==> B D' R2 D B'
373. Re: scramble for #99
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Sep 2005 10:47:33 -0000

Hi Mike :-) In fact i believe those scrambles are no longer generated by hand but by my scrambler program. Dan used to make hand-made scrambles for quite a while actually. My scrambler has flexible options for generating scrambles in the typical FMC style with repeating parts of various lenghts and also flexible number of parts. With a part i mean a non-repeating sequence, then a repeating sequence, then non- repeating again ... etc ... Unfortunately it's not perfect wrt move cancellations and/or anomalies in the repeating parts, since it was made as a simple extension to my normal scrambler. There are repeating parts in order that setting up a scramble will be easier than a plain vanilla 25/30 move sequence. So it's basically still human responsibility to check that generated scrambles are ok, as long as i haven't fixed those mentioned problems in my scrambler. Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Mike G" <m.godfrey@m...> wrote: > Just idle curiosity, but why are FMC scrambles traditionally created by > hand? I can understand why you mightn't want a near-optimal generator > produced by Cube Explorer (too depressing!), but why not a 25-turn > computer-generated scramble? > > Mike > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "c_w_tsai" <c_w_tsai@y...> > wrote: > > Hi Dan, > > > > This part of the scramble: (B D' R2 D B' )*3 > > isn't very effective :) > > > > ==> B D' R2 D B'
374. Re: scramble for #99
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Sep 2005 11:24:06 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > There are repeating parts in order that setting up a scramble will > be easier than a plain vanilla 25/30 move sequence. I somewhat disagree. It introduces an extra task, namely having to count the repetitions. Countless times did I screw up such a scramble because of that :-) Cheers! Stefan
375. Re: scramble for #99
From: "Mike G" <m.godfrey@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Sep 2005 12:06:31 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > In fact i believe those scrambles are no longer generated by hand > but by my scrambler program. Aha. > My scrambler has flexible options for > generating scrambles in the typical FMC style with repeating parts > of various lenghts and also flexible number of parts. The "anomalies" might be desirable: you could argue they add to the hand-made feel. ;) But it would not be too hard to check the order of each of the short subsequences, and then restrict the range of values for the number of repetitions accordingly. Mike
376. Re: scramble for #99
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Sep 2005 13:03:09 -0000

Oh well ... One can never satisfy everyone. Especially tricky germans ... haha ... Cheers! -Per PS! Poor Stefan. Open up the FMC Companion. Paste the scramble into the solution textarea. Then select "Show solution using FURBDL only". Then click "Set up cube" and u will get the scramble without the repeating parts (it's all been expanded for you). Now copy that again to somewhere else ;-) > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > There are repeating parts in order that setting up a scramble will > > be easier than a plain vanilla 25/30 move sequence. > > I somewhat disagree. It introduces an extra task, namely having to > count the repetitions. Countless times did I screw up such a scramble > because of that :-) > > Cheers! > Stefan
377. Re: scramble for #99
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Sep 2005 14:29:55 -0000

Hi! You mean so that not the total sequence will be too long? Well it is already somewhat restricted. U select values from dropdown comboboxes. But yes it's a good idea to display what total length would be before applying that particular pattern :-) One of the cool features is to opt for "symmetric pattern", and the program will adjust automatically ... Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Mike G" <m.godfrey@m...> wrote: > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > In fact i believe those scrambles are no longer generated by hand > > but by my scrambler program. > > Aha. > > > My scrambler has flexible options for > > generating scrambles in the typical FMC style with repeating parts > > of various lenghts and also flexible number of parts. > > The "anomalies" might be desirable: you could argue they add to the > hand-made feel. ;) > > But it would not be too hard to check the order of each of the short > subsequences, and then restrict the range of values for the number of > repetitions accordingly. > > Mike
378. Re: scramble for #99
From: "Mike G" <m.godfrey@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Sep 2005 17:17:13 -0000

Hi Per Just realized that Dan has made your program available (d'oh), so I've downloaded it. --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > You mean so that not the total sequence will be too long? I only meant if (X)^n = identity, you might not want (X)^a in your scramble if a=n, n+1, etc, since these are equivalent to shorter sequences with a=0, 1, etc. So "a" could be adjusted appropriately, or a different (X) could be used instead. > One of the cool features is to opt for "symmetric pattern", and the > program will adjust automatically ... Er... I've tried it with and without -- what should I be looking for in the ouput scrambles? Mike
379. Re: scramble for #99
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Sep 2005 21:45:02 -0000

Hi! Oh, the scrambler is not so advanced that it checks the cyclic decomposition of a sequence. That might maybe be useful. It's not very likely to encouter a part where the sequence will pass by identity with the built-in available "orders". Ok, say u have the simplest style : a [b]*k1 c [d]*k2 e If symmetric is unchecked and u have say k1=2 and k2=3. If u check symmetric again k2 changes to 3 (same as k1). For symmetry with this style length of a must be same as length of e, length of b same as length of d, and we must have k1=k2. Equivalently for the longer style. The options built in are mostly to satisfy Dan's specifications. Pluss some of my own ideas ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Mike G" <m.godfrey@m...> wrote: > Hi Per > > Just realized that Dan has made your program available (d'oh), so I've > downloaded it. > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > You mean so that not the total sequence will be too long? > > I only meant if (X)^n = identity, you might not want (X)^a in your > scramble if a=n, n+1, etc, since these are equivalent to shorter > sequences with a=0, 1, etc. So "a" could be adjusted appropriately, or > a different (X) could be used instead. > > > One of the cool features is to opt for "symmetric pattern", and the > > program will adjust automatically ... > > Er... I've tried it with and without -- what should I be looking for > in the ouput scrambles? > > Mike
380. Re: scramble for #99
From: "Mike G" <m.godfrey@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Sep 2005 08:11:15 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > Ok, say u have the simplest style : a [b]*k1 c [d]*k2 e > If symmetric is unchecked and u have say k1=2 and k2=3. If u check > symmetric again k2 changes to 3 (same as k1). Thanks, I've got it now. (Hadn't made k1/=k2.) The program doesn't actually adjust e to be equal in length to a, but I guess it isn't meant to. Mike
381. Quarterturns only :D
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 21 Sep 2005 22:02:37 -0000

Hello! So i finally made it. I solved the fmc#99 scramble using only quarter turns. I did this in 30 moves, and with 2 slice turns as a bonus ;-) It's really exciting to have done this. Am i the first to achieve this? Or at least with a reasonable length solution? I can't reveal the details of the solution until saturday for obvious reasons :-) Have fun !! -Per

383. My quarterturn only FMC#99 solution!
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 01 Oct 2005 22:29:42 -0000

Hi everyone! For FMC#99 the scramble was : D2 B' F U' L (R' D U2 B2 U2 )*3 D2 F2 L F' (B D' R2 D B' )*3 U L' B D2 R' My solution started like this : U' L' D B D B L' F' B L B D F.R This leaves 5 corners to be solved. I fix this with 2 corner 3-cycle insertions like this : first insert F' U' B U F:U' B' U at the dot and then a rather long D R B' L B R' B' L' B D' at the colon to make sure to use only quarterturns all the way :D So the final solution is then : U' L' D B D B L' F' B L B D U' B U F D R B' L B R' B' L' B D' U' B' U R It was very fun to have achieved this. My submitted best solution was 3 moves shorter (and used some half turns ... lol). Cheers! -Per

393. Question about metrics
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Oct 2005 07:54:50 -0000

In a solution (r2R) counts as 2 HTM, and 3 SQTM. But if you write it (Mr'), it may count as 3 HTM and 2 SQTM. I think this kind of questions has been asked before. What did you decide, the competitor has to choose to optimize for the metric he wants, or did you consider that since the solutions are identical you can compute the lowest score for each metric? Gilles.
394. Re: Question about metrics
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 12 Oct 2005 09:00:19 -0000

Umm ... That question is actually very interesting and relevant. For normal competitions the metric is htm so it wouldn't matter. There will be a clear UDFBRL notation when converted to that by for instance the FMC companion. But since the metric is now a combined one it does matter. I'm not quite sure how to resolve this but i guess u have to write it both (all) ways and get the metrics from FMC companion and see what comes out shorter ... So yes it is the competitor responsibility to make the solution as short as possible by notational tricks :-) -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f...> wrote: > > > In a solution (r2R) counts as 2 HTM, and 3 SQTM. > But if you write it (Mr'), it may count as 3 HTM and 2 SQTM. > > I think this kind of questions has been asked before. What did you > decide, the competitor has to choose to optimize for the metric he > wants, or did you consider that since the solutions are identical you > can compute the lowest score for each metric? > > Gilles. >

406. Re: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: fmc at wc2005
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 8 Nov 2005 09:03:23 -0800

I won. Not sure about the other positions, or even how the score was calculated. Here is the first days' scramble: (B R D2 U)x3 B U2 F D' (B2 D2 F R')x2 U' R2 B2 (D2 L D R')x2 F' L (R2 D U2 R)x3 I and Alexander Ooms both did that one in 39 to tie for first place. Not a terribly impressive number by FMC standards, but we only had 60 minutes. My 39: R B D' B2 U' B' R B' L U B U2 I don' t know about you, but full 2x2x3 block with edges oriented in 12 moves rocks *my* world any day of the week! R' B R' B R B R2 B R B' Less spectacular, but 2 full layers after 22. D R' U' R D' R' U R U2 R B F' U2 F B' R U2 And I have to finish with just a plain LL solve in 17 painful moves. Did I mention there wasn't much time? The top 4 contestants went on to the second round on Sunday, where I did 38, Per got 39, and the others less well. I'll post the second scramble later. Gotta go to work now. My second work day as a World Champion. /Lars On Nov 8, 2005, at 8:19, c_w_tsai wrote: > Did Per win?? > > And please post the scramble someone > - - - - - - - - - - - - "The mind is like a parachute. It doesn't work unless it's open." --- Frank Zappa Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com

409. Scramble 2 from wc2005
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 9 Nov 2005 09:38:41 -0800

I don't have the scramble from day 2, but here is my 38 move solution. you'll have to backtrack through it. D' U' L2 B U' L2 R U' R F R U' F' U F U F2 U F2 U2 F2 U' L D' L' U L D L' U R2 L2 D2 B' D2 R2 L2 U' Move by move analysis: Just like the first scramble, it was pretty unfriendly. It really couldn't see any good beginning, so I started by looking hard at each corner for a good 2x2x2 start. Only the last gave something useful, but it was really good: U' L2 B U' L2. Fine as far as that went, but the resulting position was again useless. So I tried a "stir and see what happens" technique I use sometimes. While building the 2x2x2, you can move any layer that does not contain any of the 4 pieces that will make up the 2x2x2 block. In this case, you can move D before move 0, 1 and 2, and also R before move 3. That's 9 different ways you can change things. After checking the third one, I didn't have to look any further: D' U' L2 B U' L2 R U' R F R. That's even one move better than my first round! I looked at a few continuations, none of which turned out well, and then I realized I had only 15 minutes left and not even a single solution to show. So I tried to stop looking for perfection, and just finish this thing off. First try was U' F' U F U F2 U F2 U2 F2 U'. I don't usually go for "pseudo" solutions, but times were desperate. If you look through the mixed up colors, you'll see this is a basic corner commutator (I call it Evelyn (http://lar5.com/cube/yE.html)), and 4 opposite edges to switch. Normally I'd try to insert them and probably cancel several moves, but when I had done them in place, written down the full resulting solution and double checked it, the time was out. At least one move cancelled between them. - - - - - - - - - - - - "He who refuses to do arithmetic is doomed to talk nonsense." --- John McCarthy Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com
410. Re: fmc at wc2005
From: "a_ooms75" <a_ooms75@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 02:29:03 -0000

This was my 39: R B D' L2 F' D F L'(2x2x2) B U' B' U' (2x2x3) D' R' D B' R' U' B' U (20 moves F2L done) F D' F' R' F R D R' [F'] (oll) [F'] F2 R2 F R F' R2 B R' F R B' (pll) got 1 cancelation of moves with it. --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > > I won. Not sure about the other positions, or even how the score was > calculated. > > Here is the first days' scramble: > > (B R D2 U)x3 B U2 F D' (B2 D2 F R')x2 U' R2 B2 (D2 L D R')x2 F' L (R2 D > U2 R)x3 > > I and Alexander Ooms both did that one in 39 to tie for first place. > Not a terribly impressive number by FMC standards, but we only had 60 > minutes. > > My 39: > R B D' B2 U' B' R B' L U B U2 > I don' t know about you, but full 2x2x3 block with edges oriented in 12 > moves rocks *my* world any day of the week! > R' B R' B R B R2 B R B' > Less spectacular, but 2 full layers after 22. > D R' U' R D' R' U R U2 R B F' U2 F B' R U2 > And I have to finish with just a plain LL solve in 17 painful moves. > Did I mention there wasn't much time? > > > > The top 4 contestants went on to the second round on Sunday, where I > did 38, Per got 39, and the others less well. > > I'll post the second scramble later. Gotta go to work now. Hi! To set up the second scramble use the following moves : R2 U D F' U B2 R2 D R' F2 L F' R D2 L2 F2 U' L2 (18 htm) This sequence i found with Cube Explorer ;-) Cheers! -Per (I erased first edition of this post cause i made mistake!) > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > > I don't have the scramble from day 2, but here is my 38 move solution. > you'll have to backtrack through it. > > D' U' L2 B U' L2 R U' R F R > U' F' U F U F2 U F2 U2 F2 U' > L D' L' U L D L' U R2 L2 D2 B' D2 R2 L2 U' > > > Move by move analysis: > > Just like the first scramble, it was pretty unfriendly.
