412. Re: Scramble 2 from wc2005
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 10 Nov 2005 18:48:58 -0000

Hi Lars! I checked ur second day solution and played with it for a little while. From ur first 9 moves i simply changed the last R turn to a half turn like this : D' U' L2 B U' L2 R U' R2 Then i continue with D' F U2 F':D Now i finish off the 5 edges with L D [L'.L] R' F R L' U'.L D' L', where the first 3 moves sets up the well known 6-move edge 5-cycle and 2 moves also cancel nicely. The remaining 3 corners are dealt with by U' R' U L2 U' R U L2 inserted at the colon, easy to see this since the edge 5-cycle is not doing anything. In fact the edge 5-cycle can be done straight after the corner 3-cycle since the last D doesn't move any of the 5 cycled edges. This trick cancels one more move. The final solution is then : D' U' L2 B U' L2 R U' R2 D' F U2 F' U' R' U L2 U' R U L' D R' F R L' U' L D' L' D (31-htm, 30 stm, 36 qtm) Pretty good from what seemed like a hard scramble :-) There should also be a better corner insertion somewhere, but this is too hard to see not allowing stickers being used. Cheers! We'd make a great team Lars ;-) -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > > I don't have the scramble from day 2, but here is my 38 move solution. > you'll have to backtrack through it. > > D' U' L2 B U' L2 R U' R F R > U' F' U F U F2 U F2 U2 F2 U' > L D' L' U L D L' U R2 L2 D2 B' D2 R2 L2 U' > > > Move by move analysis: > > Just like the first scramble, it was pretty unfriendly. It really > couldn't see any good beginning, so I started by looking hard at each > corner for a good 2x2x2 start. Only the last gave something useful, but > it was really good: U' L2 B U' L2. > > Fine as far as that went, but the resulting position was again useless. > So I tried a "stir and see what happens" technique I use sometimes. > While building the 2x2x2, you can move any layer that does not contain > any of the 4 pieces that will make up the 2x2x2 block. In this case, > you can move D before move 0, 1 and 2, and also R before move 3. That's > 9 different ways you can change things. After checking the third one, I > didn't have to look any further: D' U' L2 B U' L2 R U' R F R. That's > even one move better than my first round! > > I looked at a few continuations, none of which turned out well, and > then I realized I had only 15 minutes left and not even a single > solution to show. So I tried to stop looking for perfection, and just > finish this thing off. First try was U' F' U F U F2 U F2 U2 F2 U'. I > don't usually go for "pseudo" solutions, but times were desperate. If > you look through the mixed up colors, you'll see this is a basic corner > commutator (I call it Evelyn (http://lar5.com/cube/yE.html)), and 4 > opposite edges to switch. 413. Re: fmc at wc2005
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 11 Nov 2005 16:06:19 -0000

Hi Alexander :-) I also played a little with your first day solution. Here is what i found: I started with ur first 12 moves R B D' L2 F' D F L' B U' B' U'. Then i extended with the following: D' R' D R' B'. This leaves a postponed R move only. Luckily the corners are all solved! Here i insert a 10-move LL edge algorithm i know : B R U R2 U' B' R' D' R2 D. This cancels 4 moves and leaves an easy edge 3-cycle R2 U' D B2 U D' which cancels 1 more move with the postponed R. The final solution is then : R B D' L2 F' D F L' B U' B' U' D' R' D U R2 U' B' R' D' R2 D R' U' D B2 U D' (29 htm, 27 stm, 33 qtm) Woow! Had u only found that :-) [My solutions, i don't have them cause i didn't have time copy them to separate paper :-( ] Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "a_ooms75" <a_ooms75@y...> wrote: > > This was my 39: > R B D' L2 F' D F L'(2x2x2) > B U' B' U' (2x2x3) > D' R' D B' R' U' B' U (20 moves F2L done) > F D' F' R' F R D R' [F'] (oll) > [F'] F2 R2 F R F' R2 B R' F R B' (pll) > > got 1 cancelation of moves with it. > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@l...> > wrote: > > > > I won. Not sure about the other positions, or even how the score > was > > calculated. > > > > Here is the first days' scramble: > > > > (B R D2 U)x3 B U2 F D' (B2 D2 F R')x2 U' R2 B2 (D2 L D R')x2 F' L > (R2 D > > U2 R)x3 > > > > I and Alexander Ooms both did that one in 39 to tie for first > place. > > Not a terribly impressive number by FMC standards, but we only had > 60 > > minutes. > > > > My 39: > > R B D' B2 U' B' R B' L U B U2 > > I don' t know about you, but full 2x2x3 block with edges oriented > in 12 > > moves rocks *my* world any day of the week! > > R' B R' B R B R2 B R B' > > Less spectacular, but 2 full layers after 22. > > D R' U' R D' R' U R U2 R B F' U2 F B' R U2 > > And I have to finish with just a plain LL solve in 17 painful > moves. > > Did I mention there wasn't much time? > > > > > > > > The top 4 contestants went on to the second round on Sunday, where > I > > did 38, Per got 39, and the others less well. > > > > I'll post the second scramble later. 414. Re: fmc at wc2005
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 12 Nov 2005 15:06:32 -0000

Hi! You are priviliged to learn them now. I dare say that the 6 move 5- cycle for the edges R L' F R' L D' is trivial. It's maybe easier to see this as M D M' D'. Use a second cube to see how it works, cause not too easy to remember just like that :-) It can be used to solve 2,3 or more edges in very few moves, often with cancellations too :-) Ending w a bunch of edges is often not too bad also ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "c_w_tsai" <c_w_tsai@y...> wrote: > > > Here i > > insert a 10-move LL edge algorithm i know : B R U R2 U' B' R' D' R2 > > D. > > Maybe it's a disadvantage that I don't know those algorithms!! I also > didn't know the edge 5-cycle that you called "well-known", Per. :) > > I tried the scrambles, I found a 37 move solution to the first day's > scramble in 60 minutes. In 30 minutes with the 2nd scramble I > found ... absolutely nothing. :) Maybe I'll use the remaining 30 > minutes and try again later >
415. Re: Scramble 2 from wc2005
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 14 Nov 2005 17:42:01 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi! > > To set up the second scramble use the following moves : > > R2 U D F' U B2 R2 D R' F2 L F' R D2 L2 F2 U' L2 (18 htm) > I speedsolved this scramble (<20 secs). Basic method. I didn't try to find an optimization: U'R2FD'U2R2F R2r'U2rRU'r2RUM'(U'r' rU)R'URU2BUB'U'r' UM'UM'UMU'M'U' ---> 39 HTM, 35 STM Not bad! Gilles.

> Can you fix it? By the way, yes of course, it was a sligthly lucky solve. Gilles. PS: Sometimes I can't even believe myself. Would you trust me if I say that I solved a series of 10 cubes, 3 minutes/cube max, computer scrambled, in 34.2 STM on average?

421. Re: Scramble 2 from wc2005
From: "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 13:18:00 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > I reckon I had the same question as Per when you sent your 14.XX sec > solve for the #100 FMC challenge: do you record the solve on video and > then track the moves ? > Or are you able to repeat such a fast solve slowly in order to write > down the moves ? Just after a solve, I can remember what I did pretty well. I can't write down the moves, but I can replay the solve on a similar cube. Can't you? Since I already spent 15s on the first block, remembering the choice is easy. But sometimes I may have problems finding the same solution again for the 2nd block (especially when you panic and do stupid useless moves, but in these cases, you don't want to replay your ugly solve!). The 3rd and 4th steps are almost straightforward. When you always solve your cubes following a set of fuzzy rules, all you have to record is very few choices and rare exceptions. I suck at memorization. Stefan, you are a genius(*) is that the kind of things you can easily remember? Gilles. (*) ;-)
422. Re: Scramble 2 from wc2005
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 13:46:00 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f. > Just after a solve, I can remember what I did pretty well. I can't > write down the moves, but I can replay the solve on a similar cube. > Can't you? I would not say I could easily do it ... I would remember easily my LL (3 looks), and probably the cross ... but I'm wasting so much time during F2L that I think I would not be able to follow again my horrible options when doing the solve slowly ;-) But I'm working with my metronome (or at least with a pseudo-internal metronome in my head which I set at around 100-120 bpm), I think it's a really cool way to train thinking "ahead but not too much" ... since it's when I start trying thinking too much ahead that I completely lose concentration :)
423. Re: Scramble 2 from wc2005
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 19:06:39 -0000

Hmm !! There are ways to force ur brain to think faster. I have used this technique both for minesweeper and also speedsolving 4by and 5by cube. The principle is rather easy. If ur brain hasn't still decided what to do. Just let ur hands do "something" as a "random best choice" that will not be destructive. Eventually when practicing this ur brain will become faster and be forced to get up to speed w ur hands. This is how i have cut down my time considerably on the 5x5x5 solving. It really helps your lookahead quite incredibly. Don't be afraid to do the wrong stuff with ur hands. U will quickly get better at it. Im not sure this way of practicing will really work on the 3x3x3 since a solve is way too fast. The fastest 3x3x3 methods already are quite tabular and the recognition methods are fairly established. So it's less intuitive than larger cube solving. Well this is true for my cage method anyway. This way of practicing to become faster did help lower my minesweeper expert level time from 100 down to only 60. The best guys do low 40's however and i have no idea how they do that ... lol ... Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f. > > > Just after a solve, I can remember what I did pretty well. I can't > > write down the moves, but I can replay the solve on a similar cube. > > Can't you? > > I would not say I could easily do it ... I would remember easily my LL > (3 looks), and probably the cross ... but I'm wasting so much time > during F2L that I think I would not be able to follow again my > horrible options when doing the solve slowly ;-) But I'm working with > my metronome (or at least with a pseudo-internal metronome in my head > which I set at around 100-120 bpm), I think it's a really cool way to > train thinking "ahead but not too much" ... since it's when I start > trying thinking too much ahead that I completely lose concentration :) >
424. Re: Scramble 2 from wc2005
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 15 Nov 2005 19:19:27 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Gilles Roux" <grrroux@f. ..> wrote: > > I suck at memorization. Stefan, you are a genius(*) is that the kind > of things you can easily remember? If by "genius" you mean that I'm intelligent enough to make use of memorization methods that everybody could use just as well then I agree :-) And no, often after a solve I can't even remember which OLL I did. But I guess I could maybe replay a solve cause then I'd just see it again if I get the same F2L... Cheers! Stefan

This was posted on the speedsolvingrubikscube forum: --- In speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com, "Gunnar Krig" <gunkr520@s...> wrote: > > I was doing me dayly cube traning when I got a non-lucky 14.60, which > is a very great time for me. Since it was non-lucky I thought I should > try to solve the same scramble again a few times and see what times my > skills could give me with a solve without ANY hesitation and stops. It > didn't take long before I did 10.06 and the solution is 50 moves. I > think thats quite fast. Try if you can beat my time. The scramble is: > > U R2 F' R' U' L B U2 D R2 D L U2 F L2 B2 U L' F' U B U' R2 U2 D2 > So i was just playing around and try it on speed to solve it but then Gilles post something try a FMC so i did. in 30 min i got this: First thing i got was D U R' B' R' U' R2 U' F2 U . L' U : at the dot i added B D B' D' to get some egde oriented in LL and after that at the : B' D2 B D' R D' R' Orient and permute the edge in LL and compleet F2L. D U R' B' R' U' R2 U' F2 U B D B' D' L' U B' D2 B D' R D' R'(23h/26q/23s/26sq) and left with a 3 cycle of corners +8 moves the end will be a 31 solution. but i cant find an insert :(
429. Re: im trying
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 22 Nov 2005 09:29:02 -0000

Hi Alexander :) There is a nice 3-corner cycle that I learnt on this forum that can be quite handy ... The most trivial (well ... once you know this one) "insertion" is to apply it at the end of our solve : D U R' B' R' U' R2 U' F2 U B D B' D' L' U B' D2 B D' R D' R' (F'R'BRFR'B'R) (31,34,31,34) It's a "10 seconds" ending to your solution, I'll try if I find some more time to insert it elsewhere and cancel moves ;) I nearly never got stuck when looking for corners insertions with only two algs + L/R mirrors : that one and the classical L'URU'LUR'U'... that takes me ages but this is usually not the hardest part of the job ! cyril --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "a_ooms75" <a_ooms75@y... > > in 30 min i got this: > First thing i got was > D U R' B' R' U' R2 U' F2 U . L' U : > at the dot i added B D B' D' to get some egde oriented in LL > and after that at the : B' D2 B D' R D' R' Orient and permute the edge > in LL and compleet F2L. > > D U R' B' R' U' R2 U' F2 U B D B' D' L' U B' D2 B D' R D' > R'(23h/26q/23s/26sq) > > and left with a 3 cycle of corners +8 moves the end will be a 31 > solution. > > but i cant find an insert :( >

431. Re: fmc at wc2005 1st day
From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 23 Nov 2005 01:29:49 -0000

Nice solution, Per, finishing with edges. I finally tried one hour search for the shortest solution, too. I could not create the stress of the competition, though. What I found within half an hour was 2 layers in 18-moves as R2 U L2 F D2_ R' U L' F R U R' F R' D F' D' F and after B R' B' R D R D' R'_ R' L' D2 R D R' D2 L D' R, I got (35,40). Then I modified the first 18 moves a little to R2 U L2 F D2 R' U L' F R U R' F_ D F' D' F R', permuted the last layer pieces L' D' L D' L' D2 L D2 and finished the easy orientation D2 L D L2 F L F2 D F . Altogether, it's R2 U L2 F D2 R' U L' F R U R' F D F' D' F R' L' D' L D' L' D2 L2 D L2 F L F2 D F (32,40) which I had luckily in about 53 minutes. With the second day scramble I was not doing very good and couldn't improve a 38-HTM (that I had in about 35 min) move within one hour. I don't post it here because it's not any interesting. It was 4 corner ending. Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi Alexander :-) > > I also played a little with your first day solution. Here is what i > found: > > I started with ur first 12 moves R B D' L2 F' D F L' B U' B' U'. > Then i extended with the following: D' R' D R' B'. This leaves a > postponed R move only. Luckily the corners are all solved! Here i > insert a 10-move LL edge algorithm i know : B R U R2 U' B' R' D' R2 > D. This cancels 4 moves and leaves an easy edge 3-cycle R2 U' D B2 U > D' which cancels 1 more move with the postponed R. The final > solution is then : > > R B D' L2 F' D F L' B U' B' U' D' R' D U R2 U' B' R' D' R2 D R' U' D > B2 U D' (29 htm, 27 stm, 33 qtm) > > Woow! Had u only found that :-) > > [My solutions, i don't have them cause i didn't have time copy them > to separate paper :-( ] > > Cheers! > > -Per > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "a_ooms75" > <a_ooms75@y...> wrote: > > > > This was my 39: > > R B D' L2 F' D F L'(2x2x2) > > B U' B' U' (2x2x3) > > D' R' D B' R' U' B' U (20 moves F2L done) > > F D' F' R' F R D R' [F'] (oll) > > [F'] F2 R2 F R F' R2 B R' F R B' (pll) > > > > got 1 cancelation of moves with it. > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus > <lars@l...> > > wrote: > > > > > > I won. Not sure about the other positions, or even how the score > > was > > > calculated. > > > > > > Here is the first days' scramble: > > > > > > (B R D2 U)x3 B U2 F D' (B2 D2 F R')x2 U' R2 B2 (D2 L D R')x2 F' > L > > (R2 D > > > U2 R)x3 > > > > > > I and Alexander Ooms both did that one in 39 to tie for first > > place. > > > Not a terribly impressive number by FMC standards, but we only > had > > 60 > > > minutes. > > > > > > My 39: > > > R B D' B2 U' B' R B' L U B U2 > > > I don' t know about you, but full 2x2x3 block with edges > oriented > > in 12 > > > moves rocks *my* world any day of the week! > > > R' B R' B R B R2 B R B' > > > Less spectacular, but 2 full layers after 22. > > > D R' U' R D' R' U R U2 R B F' U2 F B' R U2 > > > And I have to finish with just a plain LL solve in 17 painful > > moves. > > > Did I mention there wasn't much time? > > > > > > > > > > > > The top 4 contestants went on to the second round on Sunday, > where > > I > > > did 38, Per got 39, and the others less well. > > > > > > I'll post the second scramble later. The final > > solution is then : > > > > R B D' L2 F' D F L' B U' B' U' D' R' D U R2 U' B' R' D' R2 D R' U' > D > > B2 U D' (29 htm, 27 stm, 33 qtm) > > > > Woow! Had u only found that :-) > > > > [My solutions, i don't have them cause i didn't have time copy them > > to separate paper :-( ] > > > > Cheers! > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "a_ooms75" > > <a_ooms75@y...> wrote: > > > > > > This was my 39: > > > R B D' L2 F' D F L'(2x2x2) > > > B U' B' U' (2x2x3) > > > D' R' D B' R' U' B' U (20 moves F2L done) > > > F D' F' R' F R D R' [F'] (oll) > > > [F'] F2 R2 F R F' R2 B R' F R B' (pll) > > > > > > got 1 cancelation of moves with it. > > > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@...m, Lars Petrus > > <lars@l...> > > > wrote: > > > > > > > > I won. Not sure about the other positions, or even how the > score > > > was > > > > calculated. > > > > > > > > Here is the first days' scramble: > > > > > > > > (B R D2 U)x3 B U2 F D' (B2 D2 F R')x2 U' R2 B2 (D2 L D R')x2 F' > > L > > > (R2 D > > > > U2 R)x3 > > > > > > > > I and Alexander Ooms both did that one in 39 to tie for first > > > place. > > > > Not a terribly impressive number by FMC standards, but we only > > had > > > 60 > > > > minutes. > > > > > > > > My 39: > > > > R B D' B2 U' B' R B' L U B U2 > > > > I don' t know about you, but full 2x2x3 block with edges > > oriented > > > in 12 > > > > moves rocks *my* world any day of the week! > > > > R' B R' B R B R2 B R B' > > > > Less spectacular, but 2 full layers after 22. > > > > D R' U' R D' R' U R U2 R B F' U2 F B' R U2 > > > > And I have to finish with just a plain LL solve in 17 painful > > > moves. > > > > Did I mention there wasn't much time? > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > The top 4 contestants went on to the second round on Sunday, > > where > > > I > > > > did 38, Per got 39, and the others less well. > > > > > > > > I'll post the second scramble later. Gotta go to work now. My > > > second > > > > work day as a World Champion. > > > > > > > > /Lars > > > > > > > > On Nov 8, 2005, at 8:19, c_w_tsai wrote: > > > > > > > > > Did Per win?? > > > > > > > > > > And please post the scramble someone > > > > > > > > > - - - - - - - - - - - - > > > > "The mind is like a parachute. From: "mirek_goljan" <goljan@...>

Date: Mon, 28 Nov 2005 02:28:25 -0000

Per, if I find the scratch paper with that 4-corner finish (one twisted corner and tree-cycle if I remember it right), I'll post it here later. I remember not really looking for good insertions because I thought I might be better off spending time with looking for a different shorter solution; not that I can't do it without stickers. Mirek --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi Mirek :-) > > Really nice 18-move f2l. And yes a rather lucky finish with 2 easy > short algs with some cancelled moved :-) There is always some luck > with short solutions. 32 moves i consider short for only 1 hr and no > stickers. I'm too slow for 1 hr solving. Need to practice it. > Umm ... i recall i did that Dallas (??) fewest moves scramble in 33 > moves in like 25 minutes. But that was a nice scramble ;-) > > I would like to see ur solution with 4 corner finish. I wonder if u > found some good cancellations by not using stickers. Ans also if u > had 3-cycle and a twisted corner or 2 2-cycles :-) > > -Per > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "mirek_goljan" > <goljan@s...> wrote: > > > > Nice solution, Per, finishing with edges. > > I finally tried one hour search for the shortest solution, too. I > > could not create the stress of the competition, though. > > What I found within half an hour was 2 layers in 18-moves as > > R2 U L2 F D2_ R' U L' F R U R' F R' D F' D' F and after B R' B' R > D R > > D' R'_ R' L' D2 R D R' D2 L D' R, I got (35,40). > > Then I modified the first 18 moves a little to > > R2 U L2 F D2 R' U L' F R U R' F_ D F' D' F R', permuted the last > > layer pieces L' D' L D' L' D2 L D2 and finished the easy > orientation > > D2 L D L2 F L F2 D F . Altogether, it's > > R2 U L2 F D2 R' U L' F R U R' F D F' D' F R' L' D' L D' L' D2 L2 D > L2 > > F L F2 D F (32,40) which I had luckily in about 53 minutes. > > > > With the second day scramble I was not doing very good and > couldn't > > improve a 38-HTM (that I had in about 35 min) move within one > hour. I > > don't post it here because it's not any interesting. It was 4 > corner > > ending. > > Mirek > > > > > > > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen > Fredlund" > > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > > > Hi Alexander :-) > > > > > > I also played a little with your first day solution. Here is > what i > > > found: > > > > > > I started with ur first 12 moves R B D' L2 F' D F L' B U' B' > U'. > > > Then i extended with the following: D' R' D R' B'. This leaves a > > > postponed R move only. Luckily the corners are all solved! Here > i > > > insert a 10-move LL edge algorithm i know : B R U R2 U' B' R' D' > R2 > > > D. This cancels 4 moves and leaves an easy edge 3-cycle R2 U' D > B2 > > U > > > D' which cancels 1 more move with the postponed R. The final > > > solution is then : > > > > > > R B D' L2 F' D F L' B U' B' U' D' R' D U R2 U' B' R' D' R2 D R' > U' > > D > > > B2 U D' (29 htm, 27 stm, 33 qtm) > > > > > > Woow! 438. Re: Nearly good solutions
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Nov 2005 16:35:01 -0000

Hi fellowship .... ;-) Browsing through ur interesting discussions for FMC #100 i found the following start: F' R D R' D' B' D2 L U L' D2 L' R B' L R' You seem to have missed another nearly good solution from this start. Simply add F' U B' U' F U2 B' U D' gives 3 twisted corners in (25,28,22,25) This is better than ur other nearly good solution with also 3 twisted corners :D Cheers! -Per PS! We also had a bunch of interesting starts leading "nowhere" but now all that is lost ...
439. Re: Nearly good solutions
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 30 Nov 2005 16:57:37 -0000

Hi Per ! Did you visit the forum on my website ? We found it really handy for exchanging information about this horrible scramble. Everyone is free to post as guest on ths forum ... Btw I found another frustratig solution last week : {F B'} D' L B L' U' D2 B R2 B2 U' F' U L' F' L' leaves 5 corners after 17 moves. I found two fantastically lousy insertions to end up with (30,36,29,35), but I'm really sure it's possible to finish under 30 ! {F B'} D' (D'FUF'DFU'F') L B L' U' D2 B R2 B2 U' F' U L' F' (UL'D2LU'L'D2) (30,36,29,35) or {F B'} D' L B L' U' D2 B R2 B2 U' F' U L' F' (U L'D2 L (LF'R'FL'F'RF) U'L'D2) (30,36,29,35) I found interesting to post our partial solutions as well, since I know that you, Mirek and others are always glad to demonstrate that we could have done better ;) What do you think of our incredible ultimate team solve ? I wish there is such a competition at EC2006 or WC2007 ;) Thanks Dan for the results, that was really fun to compete in teams (although I still can't imagine how you managed to produce such a frustrating scramble, I was expecting UWR broken by at least half of the teams before you published it), I'll miss Gilles and Lars for the next challenges I guess ... Congrats to all participants, I noticed some speedcubers' names in the results table, cool :D cyril --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi fellowship .... ;-) > > Browsing through ur interesting discussions for FMC #100 i found the > following start: > > F' R D R' D' B' D2 L U L' D2 L' R B' L R' > > You seem to have missed another nearly good solution from this > start. Hi ;.) I think your group was more or less the only one that was working really well together as a team. Lars' no-insertion 27-move solution is really cool. Yes i found that start of yours from ur discussion forum :-) Actually, my best ever near-solution with only 2 twisted corners was 17 moves. This was quite a while ago, and i guess i'd find it if i browse past fmc results. It was found using insertions with stickers and backtracking. Saving 3 moves on inserting 2 corner 3-cycles is not very good, yes. But i have seen worse scenarios ... I've never really practiced nor even tried to do something really nice and interesting in fewest move but at the WC, I was really impressed by that. That's why I'm thinking about starting to practice FM a bit :-) Is there anything that a beginner should know before he starts ? or can I just give it a go and try to do my best ? Thank you :-) Gilles.

446. Re: How to start with fewest moves ?
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 08 Dec 2005 14:19:23 -0000

Hi Gilles, I participated to my first FMC 1 year ago for the special Xmas FMC (btw Dan, are you going to organise another one this year ?) ... 47 moves for solving the cube, quite pathetic ;-) Now I average around 29-32 I guess, mainly because : 1) I re-learnt Petrus solution instead of trying to work with Fridrich related methods 2) I better understand the edges orientation step of his method 3) I better "see" and follow the 2x2x3 pieces while I'm building it 4) I learnt about setup moves and pseudo-blocks 5) I learnt about commutators for corners and basic edges cycles 6) I've been quite lucky while solving the cube like : 2x2x3, edges orientation, 2 2x2x1, last 3 edges, insert a commutator for the last 3 corners 7) I now spent MUCH MORE time on the scrambles 8) It allows me for getting lucky more often ... There are many other ways like edges-first solutions (Per is the only specialist on Earth I think), STM optimisation (Gilles R. has been trying for years to change the official metric since his method is incredible for this), 2-Generator finish (Charles, Sebastian are specialists). I guess the best is to begin slowly and aim good Petrus solves. Then learn some other techniques like insertions and pseudo blocks, this forum is full of posts about them ;-) Good luck ! cyril --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@g. ..> wrote: > > Hello, > > For those of you who don't know me : I'm Gilles van den Peereboom from > Belgium. > I've never really practiced nor even tried to do something really nice > and interesting in fewest move but at the WC, I was really impressed > by that. > That's why I'm thinking about starting to practice FM a bit :-) > > Is there anything that a beginner should know before he starts ? or > can I just give it a go and try to do my best ? > > Thank you :-) > Gilles. >

Hi all, I don't post on the FMC forum very often, but Cyril! our solutions are identical in approach! The one thing I've been working on a bit (and haven't had a chance to apply it yet in FMC) is watching edge orientation very early in the solve. I've been trying to solve a 2x2x3 block+have all edges oriented. I've been inconsistent in this, but it seems promising. --- Cyril Castella <cyrilca@...> wrote: > Hi Gilles, > I participated to my first FMC 1 year ago for the > special Xmas FMC > (btw Dan, are you going to organise another one this > year ?) > ... 47 moves for solving the cube, quite pathetic > ;-) > Now I average around 29-32 I guess, mainly because : > 1) I re-learnt Petrus solution instead of trying to > work with Fridrich > related methods > 2) I better understand the edges orientation step of > his method > 3) I better "see" and follow the 2x2x3 pieces while > I'm building it > 4) I learnt about setup moves and pseudo-blocks > 5) I learnt about commutators for corners and basic > edges cycles > 6) I've been quite lucky while solving the cube like > : 2x2x3, edges > orientation, 2 2x2x1, last 3 edges, insert a > commutator for the last 3 > corners > 7) I now spent MUCH MORE time on the scrambles > 8) It allows me for getting lucky more often ... > > There are many other ways like edges-first solutions > (Per is the only > specialist on Earth I think), STM optimisation > (Gilles R. has been > trying for years to change the official metric since > his method is > incredible for this), 2-Generator finish (Charles, > Sebastian are > specialists). 448. Re: How to start with fewest moves ?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 13:50:38 -0000

Hi :-) And add to that list of tools and tricks the most useful one for me : - INSERTIONS !! Without those i would never have achieved all my really short solutions. The prime candidates for insertion are corner or edge 3- cycles. But any algorithm that shifts few pieces around are good candidates for trying to find some insertion for them that will give move cancellations. I guess starting with looking into corner 3- cycle insertions is ur best bet. It's not all that hard when putting stickers (numbered) on the corners to be cycles in such a way that the orientation is correct. There are many posts in this groups about this topc. Just search for them :-) Some more hints: - cross first with clever c/e inserts can be good. Use slanting corner technique when needed - starting w 2x2x2 block is also good (better), gives many options - if you can do directly a 2x2x3 and skipping the 2x2x2 it can save u moves, but this requires more experience - the ultimate method for me now is doing "edges first", this however takes me ages and is impossible timewise in competitions - generally i always aim for a start (skeleton solution) where i am left with a few cycles (edges or corners) to be done w insertions - basic insight into "cycle structures" is also useful, for instance ending with corner 5-cycle is not any worse than ending w corner 3- cycle and a twisted corner, both are dealt with by 2 3-cycles .. and so on ... - advanced techniques : scramble premove(s), solve the inverse scramble instead, use the "put all into one layer and solve it"- method ... There is lots of fun in the world of fewest moves ;-) Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > > Hi Gilles, > I participated to my first FMC 1 year ago for the special Xmas FMC > (btw Dan, are you going to organise another one this year ?) > ... 47 moves for solving the cube, quite pathetic ;-) > Now I average around 29-32 I guess, mainly because : > 1) I re-learnt Petrus solution instead of trying to work with Fridrich > related methods > 2) I better understand the edges orientation step of his method > 3) I better "see" and follow the 2x2x3 pieces while I'm building it > 4) I learnt about setup moves and pseudo-blocks > 5) I learnt about commutators for corners and basic edges cycles > 6) I've been quite lucky while solving the cube like : 2x2x3, edges > orientation, 2 2x2x1, last 3 edges, insert a commutator for the last 3 > corners > 7) I now spent MUCH MORE time on the scrambles > 8) It allows me for getting lucky more often ... > > There are many other ways like edges-first solutions (Per is the only > specialist on Earth I think), STM optimisation (Gilles R. has been > trying for years to change the official metric since his method is > incredible for this), 2-Generator finish (Charles, Sebastian are > specialists). I guess the best is to begin slowly and aim good Petrus > solves. Then learn some other techniques like insertions and pseudo > blocks, this forum is full of posts about them ;-) > > Good luck ! > > cyril > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "gillesvdp" <gillesvdp@g. > ..> wrote: > > > > Hello, > > > > For those of you who don't know me : I'm Gilles van den Peereboom > from > > Belgium. > > I've never really practiced nor even tried to do something really > nice > > and interesting in fewest move but at the WC, I was really impressed > > by that. > > That's why I'm thinking about starting to practice FM a bit :-) > > > > Is there anything that a beginner should know before he starts ? or > > can I just give it a go and try to do my best ? > > > > Thank you :-) > > Gilles. > > >
449. Re: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: How to start with fewest moves ?
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 9 Dec 2005 15:51:35 +0100

Hello :-) It's gunne that edges first was actually my first method for speedcubing :p Maybe I'll use some of the tricks I used a while ago. I'll try a scrambler later today and I'll tell you what I came up with :-) Thank you for all the hints ! Gilles. 2005/12/9, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@...>: > Hi :-) > > And add to that list of tools and tricks the most useful one for me : > > - INSERTIONS !! > > Without those i would never have achieved all my really short > solutions. The prime candidates for insertion are corner or edge 3- > cycles. But any algorithm that shifts few pieces around are good > candidates for trying to find some insertion for them that will give > move cancellations. I guess starting with looking into corner 3- > cycle insertions is ur best bet. It's not all that hard when putting > stickers (numbered) on the corners to be cycles in such a way that > the orientation is correct. There are many posts in this groups > about this topc. Just search for them :-) > > Some more hints: > > - cross first with clever c/e inserts can be good. Use slanting > corner technique when needed > > - starting w 2x2x2 block is also good (better), gives many options > > - if you can do directly a 2x2x3 and skipping the 2x2x2 it can save > u moves, but this requires more experience > > - the ultimate method for me now is doing "edges first", this > however takes me ages and is impossible timewise in competitions > > - generally i always aim for a start (skeleton solution) where i am > left with a few cycles (edges or corners) to be done w insertions > > - basic insight into "cycle structures" is also useful, for instance > ending with corner 5-cycle is not any worse than ending w corner 3- > cycle and a twisted corner, both are dealt with by 2 3-cycles .. and > so on ... > > - advanced techniques : scramble premove(s), solve the inverse > scramble instead, use the "put all into one layer and solve it"- > method ... > > There is lots of fun in the world of fewest moves ;-) > > Cheers! > > -Per > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" > <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > > > > Hi Gilles, > > I participated to my first FMC 1 year ago for the special Xmas FMC > > (btw Dan, are you going to organise another one this year ?) > > ... 47 moves for solving the cube, quite pathetic ;-) > > Now I average around 29-32 I guess, mainly because : > > 1) I re-learnt Petrus solution instead of trying to work with > Fridrich > > related methods > > 2) I better understand the edges orientation step of his method > > 3) I better "see" and follow the 2x2x3 pieces while I'm building it > > 4) I learnt about setup moves and pseudo-blocks > > 5) I learnt about commutators for corners and basic edges cycles > > 6) I've been quite lucky while solving the cube like : 2x2x3, > edges > > orientation, 2 2x2x1, last 3 edges, insert a commutator for the > last 3 > > corners > > 7) I now spent MUCH MORE time on the scrambles > > 8) It allows me for getting lucky more often ... > > > > There are many other ways like edges-first solutions (Per is the > only > > specialist on Earth I think), STM optimisation (Gilles R. has been > > trying for years to change the official metric since his method is > > incredible for this), 2-Generator finish (Charles, Sebastian are > > specialists). I guess the best is to begin slowly and aim good > Petrus > > solves. Then learn some other techniques like insertions and > pseudo > > blocks, this forum is full of posts about them ;-) > > > > Good luck ! > > > > cyril > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "gillesvdp" > <gillesvdp@g. > > ..> wrote: > > > > > > Hello, > > > > > > For those of you who don't know me : I'm Gilles van den > Peereboom > > from > > > Belgium. > > > I've never really practiced nor even tried to do something > really > > nice > > > and interesting in fewest move but at the WC, I was really > impressed > > > by that. > > > That's why I'm thinking about starting to practice FM a bit :-) > > > > > > Is there anything that a beginner should know before he starts ? > or > > > can I just give it a go and try to do my best ? > > > > > > Thank you :-) > > > Gilles. > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > >
450. Re: How to start with fewest moves ?
From: "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 15:41:24 -0000

Be careful Gilles, you should not try #100 scramble, that one was one of the toughest Dan had ever proposed ;-) But I would advise to choose one of the latest FMC scrambles, so you can compare with other solutions once you've come up with yours ... Per, I was speaking about insertions when I mentioned commutators, I should have made things clearer :) Btw, what would be the optimal way (in terms of optimisation time/number of cancelled moves) one should use for inserting 2 corner-cycles, for example for solving 1 5-cycle ? Let's call the corners to be cycled 1-2-3-4-5 (in that order) I usually look for the best 1-2-3 cycle, then for the best 1-4-5 remaing cycle, then I look only for groovy insertions of other "primary" cycle (2-3-4, 3-4-5 or 4-5-1), and eventually look further if they are REALLY promising. What about your strategy ? Do you always check all "primary cycles" before trying to complete the solution ? I usually try to avoid 5-cycles, since I know it is usually very long for me ... cyril
451. Re: How to start with fewest moves ?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 09 Dec 2005 18:39:57 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > > Be careful Gilles, you should not try #100 scramble, that one was one > of the toughest Dan had ever proposed ;-) Which one? http://www.cosine-systems.com/cubestation/fmcresults/fmc.php *Scramble Algorithm for 28/10/05 FMC #100* R B' U F' U' R2 F U2 R D' F' U B2 R2 F U2 F2 D' B L2 B2 L' D L F http://www.cosine-systems.com/cubestation/fmcresults/teamfmc100.php Team FMC#100 Scramble L' R' D R (B2 D2 R B F2)*4 U B R' D2 (L' R2 U' F U')*4 F2 L F B Stefan

Cheers! Stefan P.S. Unix rules... echo "(alg)" | tr wyorgb DUBFLR
453. Re: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: How to start with fewest moves ?
From: Gilles van den Peereboom <gillesvdp@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 9 Dec 2005 23:51:32 +0100

Actuallly I tried this scramble (generated with Stefan's page) : D' F' R2 B2 L U' F R F' D' F U2 F2 D U2 F2 B' L' B L D U L' F U' At the beginning I did my normal Fridrich technique and got a 63 move solution. Then I changed something for the last pair and I got a ZBLL case I know on the LL (14 moves). 48 moves :U2 L' D' F D R2 B' R2 B L2 U L U F U F' U F' U F B' U B U L F L' R U2 R' U' R U R' y L U L2 U' L2 U' L2 U2 L U' L U' L' U I'll try the #99 FMC scramble tomorrow :-) This is a really nice challenge :D Gilles. 2005/12/9, Stefan Pochmann <pochmann@...>: > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > http://www.cosine-systems.com/cubestation/fmcresults/teamfmc100.php > > Team FMC#100 Scramble > > L' R' D R (B2 D2 R B F2)*4 U B R' D2 (L' R2 U' F U')*4 F2 L F B > > For this one, I just found this almost-solution: > F' R D R' L' D' B D' R U' L' U L U2 B U' B' U2 R2 U R' U R U2 R' U' > But I don't have time to really get into it now... > > Cheers! > Stefan > > P.S. 454. Re: How to start with fewest moves ?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sun, 11 Dec 2005 11:49:58 -0000

Hi! I put stickers on all 5 corners then and look for best insertion for all 5 candidates at every insertion point. It's not all that hard but yes not trivially easy either. Looking at 5 different ones at every step requires full concentration to not miss anything. Then i pick the best insertion and then i look for the remaining insert. So i can't really be sure it's the global optimum insert scheme :-( Cheers! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > > Be careful Gilles, you should not try #100 scramble, that one was one > of the toughest Dan had ever proposed ;-) But I would advise to choose > one of the latest FMC scrambles, so you can compare with other > solutions once you've come up with yours ... > > Per, I was speaking about insertions when I mentioned commutators, I > should have made things clearer :) Btw, what would be the optimal way > (in terms of optimisation time/number of cancelled moves) one should > use for inserting 2 corner-cycles, for example for solving 1 5- cycle ? > Let's call the corners to be cycled 1-2-3-4-5 (in that order) > I usually look for the best 1-2-3 cycle, then for the best 1-4-5 > remaing cycle, then I look only for groovy insertions of other > "primary" cycle (2-3-4, 3-4-5 or 4-5-1), and eventually look further > if they are REALLY promising. What about your strategy ? Do you always > check all "primary cycles" before trying to complete the solution ? I > usually try to avoid 5-cycles, since I know it is usually very long > for me ... > > cyril >

463. 2x2x2 FMC ;-)
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Mon, 19 Dec 2005 19:32:41 -0000

Hi guys :-) At http://www.svekub.se they have launched a 2x2x2 fewest moves challenge. The scramble is as follows : B R B' R' F' R' F L D B R F R2 B' U2 L D' B2 L' F2 L' U2 B2 D B' So far i have done a 10-move solution. Let's see how well u guys can do it. Send your solutions to perkrif(at]idi(dot]ntnu(dot]no For those of you who can read swedish i have posted my solution here: (spoils some fun ... ) http://www.svekub.se/component/option,com_simpleboard/Itemid,43/func, view/id,4378/catid,11/ Have fun! -Per
464. Re: Scramble 2 from wc2005
From: "richy_jr_2000" <richy_jr_2000@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 20 Dec 2005 01:07:01 -0000

I made another attempt at this scramble since my situation was not favorable in the 2nd round. I found this solution in <1 hour. Too bad I had not seen it sooner. R2 F2 U2 F R F2 D F2 D2 U' R U2 R2 L' U2 L R' F R F' R' F R D' F2 D F D' F D F2 Let me know what you think --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi! > > To set up the second scramble use the following moves : > > R2 U D F' U B2 R2 D R' F2 L F' R D2 L2 F2 U' L2 (18 htm) > > This sequence i found with Cube Explorer ;-) > > Cheers! > > -Per > > (I erased first edition of this post cause i made mistake!) > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus > <lars@l...> wrote: > > > > I don't have the scramble from day 2, but here is my 38 move > solution. > > you'll have to backtrack through it. > > > > D' U' L2 B U' L2 R U' R F R > > U' F' U F U F2 U F2 U2 F2 U' > > L D' L' U L D L' U R2 L2 D2 B' D2 R2 L2 U' > > > > > > Move by move analysis: > > > > Just like the first scramble, it was pretty unfriendly. It really > > couldn't see any good beginning, so I started by looking hard at > each > > corner for a good 2x2x2 start. Only the last gave something > useful, but > > it was really good: U' L2 B U' L2. > > > > Fine as far as that went, but the resulting position was again > useless. > > So I tried a "stir and see what happens" technique I use > sometimes. > > While building the 2x2x2, you can move any layer that does not > contain > > any of the 4 pieces that will make up the 2x2x2 block. In this > case, > > you can move D before move 0, 1 and 2, and also R before move 3. > That's > > 9 different ways you can change things. After checking the third > one, I > > didn't have to look any further: D' U' L2 B U' L2 R U' R F R. > That's > > even one move better than my first round! > > > > I looked at a few continuations, none of which turned out well, > and > > then I realized I had only 15 minutes left and not even a single > > solution to show. So I tried to stop looking for perfection, and > just > > finish this thing off. First try was U' F' U F U F2 U F2 U2 F2 U'. > I > > don't usually go for "pseudo" solutions, but times were desperate. > If > > you look through the mixed up colors, you'll see this is a basic > corner > > commutator (I call it Evelyn (http://lar5.com/cube/yE.html)), and > 4 > > opposite edges to switch. Normally I'd try to insert them and > probably > > cancel several moves, but when I had done them in place, written > down > > the full resulting solution and double checked it, the time was > out. At > > least one move cancelled between them. > > > > - - - - - - - - - - - - > > "He who refuses to do arithmetic is doomed to talk nonsense." > > --- John McCarthy > > > > Lars Petrus - lars@l... http://lar5.com > > >

Date: Wed, 21 Dec 2005 10:55:39 -0000

466. Christmas Challenge FMC
From: "Dan Harris" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: <speedsolvingrubikscube@yahoogroups.com>, <fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com>
Date: Fri, 23 Dec 2005 17:52:16 -0000

Hi everyone! The FMC is back for Christmas! This year, similar to last year, we will have a special challenge over Christmas. This year there are a few more events, but the format is the same! You have to find the shortest solution for each category; you can take part in as many or as few events as you wish! The categories are: * Shortest solution to complete one face * Shortest solution to complete one layer (not a middle layer) * Shortest solution to any 1x2x3 block (a Roux block) * Shortest solution to 2 complete Roux blocks (Roux step 2.) * Shortest solution to any 2x2x2 block * Shortest solution to any 2x2x3 block * Shortest solution to the F2L * Shortest solution to solve all edges * Shortest solution to solve all corners * Shortest solution to the whole cube You have two weeks in which to submit your entries, and the competition details and the scramble can all be found at my website - www.cubestation.co.uk <http://www.cubestation.co.uk/> and follow the FMC link. Good Luck everybody, let's make this challenge the biggest yet! DanH :)
467. Re: [fewestmoveschallenge] Christmas Challenge FMC
From: Pedro <pedrosino1@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 23 Dec 2005 17:17:39 -0300 (ART)

Hey, Dan where is the scramble? I can't find it... Pedro Dan Harris <dan_j_harris@...> escreveu: Hi everyone! The FMC is back for Christmas! This year, similar to last year, we will have a special challenge over Christmas. This year there are a few more events, but the format is the same! You have to find the shortest solution for each category; you can take part in as many or as few events as you wish! The categories are: Shortest solution to complete one face Shortest solution to complete one layer (not a middle layer) Shortest solution to any 1x2x3 block (a Roux block) Shortest solution to 2 complete Roux blocks (Roux step 2.) Shortest solution to any 2x2x2 block Shortest solution to any 2x2x3 block Shortest solution to the F2L Shortest solution to solve all edges Shortest solution to solve all corners Shortest solution to the whole cube You have two weeks in which to submit your entries, and the competition details and the scramble can all be found at my website www.cubestation.co.uk and follow the FMC link. Good Luck everybody, lets make this challenge the biggest yet! DanH :) SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO! Sorry, I forgot to say, as with all FMC's, it will be launched at Midnight tonight (UK time) :) Dan :) --- In fewestmoveschallenge@...m, Pedro <pedrosino1@y...> wrote: > > Hey, Dan > where is the scramble? I can't find it... > > Pedro > > Dan Harris <dan_j_harris@n...> escreveu: > Hi everyone! > > The FMC is back for Christmas! This year, similar to last year, we will have a special challenge over Christmas. > > This year there are a few more events, but the format is the same! You have to find the shortest solution for each category; you can take part in as many or as few events as you wish! > The categories are: > > > Shortest solution to complete one face > Shortest solution to complete one layer > (not a middle layer) > Shortest solution to any 1x2x3 block > (a Roux block) > Shortest solution to 2 complete Roux blocks > (Roux step 2.) > Shortest solution to any 2x2x2 block > Shortest solution to any 2x2x3 block > Shortest solution to the F2L > Shortest solution to solve all edges > Shortest solution to solve all corners > Shortest solution to the whole cube > > You have two weeks in which to submit your entries, and the competition details and the scramble can all be found at my website www.cubestation.co.uk and follow the FMC link. > Good Luck everybody, let's make this challenge the biggest yet! > > DanH :) > > > > > SPONSORED LINKS > Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games > > --------------------------------- > YAHOO! 469. guaranteed optimality under N moves ?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 24 Dec 2005 17:55:06 -0000

Question about 3x3 for the theory guys: Imagine I have an N move solution and I'm not stupid (i.e. I don't do stuff like R R2). For which N can I be sure that my solution is optimal, i.e. no shorter solution can exist? I could imagine N being as large as about 5... Cheers! Stefan
470. Re: [fewestmoveschallenge] guaranteed optimality under N moves ?
From: Lars Petrus <lars@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 24 Dec 2005 10:30:02 -0800

I think the theoretical answer is that "It depends on the position". Here is a similar question, that may be what you're trying to ask (but I doubt it): What is the shortest non trivial case where two different algorithms of the same length produce the same position? I believe there is a LL case with two different 8 move algs solving the same position. There are probably shorter examples for the general case. /Lars On Dec 24, 2005, at 9:55, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > Question about 3x3 for the theory guys: > > Imagine I have an N move solution and I'm not stupid (i.e. I don't do > stuff like R R2). For which N can I be sure that my solution is > optimal, i.e. no shorter solution can exist? > > I could imagine N being as large as about 5... > > Cheers! > Stefan - - - - - - - - - - - - "The mind is like a parachute. It doesn't work unless it's open." --- Frank Zappa Lars Petrus - lars@... http://lar5.com
471. Re: guaranteed optimality under N moves ?
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 24 Dec 2005 21:51:53 -0000

Yeah, my wording was a bit unfortunate. What I meant was a rule like this: "Every non-stupid solution with 5 moves or less is optimal." That is, a guarantee over all cube states. The task is is to find the correct number (5 is just a guess). It's indeed similar to your question. Obviously if N doesn't give you an optimality-guarantee, then neither does N+1. So it's valid for all numbers 0..G and not for G+1..infinity and we have to find that G. The number G+1 is the smallest number that doesn't guarantee optimality, meaning there's a cube state that can be solved in G+1 moves (your solution) but also in fewer moves (optimal solution). Here's proof that length 7 is *no* guarantee for optimality: U' R U' B U B' R' can be achieved shorter with F R' F' R U' Cheers! Stefan --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, Lars Petrus <lars@l...> wrote: > > I think the theoretical answer is that "It depends on the position". > > > Here is a similar question, that may be what you're trying to ask (but > I doubt it): > > What is the shortest non trivial case where two different algorithms of > the same length produce the same position? > > I believe there is a LL case with two different 8 move algs solving the > same position. There are probably shorter examples for the general > case. > > /Lars > > On Dec 24, 2005, at 9:55, Stefan Pochmann wrote: > > > Question about 3x3 for the theory guys: > > > > Imagine I have an N move solution and I'm not stupid (i.e. I don't do > > stuff like R R2). For which N can I be sure that my solution is > > optimal, i.e. no shorter solution can exist? > > > > I could imagine N being as large as about 5... > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > > - - - - - - - - - - - - > "The mind is like a parachute. It doesn't work unless it's open." > --- Frank Zappa > > Lars Petrus - lars@l... http://lar5.com >

This year, similar to last year, we will > have a special challenge over Christmas. > > > > This year there are a few more events, but the format is the same! You have > to find the shortest solution for each category; you can take part in as > many or as few events as you wish! > > The categories are: > > > > * Shortest solution to complete one face > * Shortest solution to complete one layer > (not a middle layer) > * Shortest solution to any 1x2x3 block > (a Roux block) > * Shortest solution to 2 complete Roux blocks > (Roux step 2.) > * Shortest solution to any 2x2x2 block > * Shortest solution to any 2x2x3 block > * Shortest solution to the F2L > * Shortest solution to solve all edges > * Shortest solution to solve all corners > * Shortest solution to the whole cube > > > > You have two weeks in which to submit your entries, and the competition > details and the scramble can all be found at my website - > www.cubestation.co.uk <http://www.cubestation.co.uk/> and follow the FMC > link. > > Good Luck everybody, let's make this challenge the biggest yet! > > > > DanH :) >
473. Re: guaranteed optimality under N moves ?
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 24 Dec 2005 22:55:41 -0000

Hi :-) R' D' R F D2 L can be achieved with D2 F L D' Thats the shortest one i know ;-) And then also : R' D' R F D2 can be achieved with D2 F L D' L' (can split as desired ... ) So, yes maybe 4 is the maximum ... hmm ?? I guess that several optimal solutions should be allowed. Uniquely minimal is not necessary. Cheers! -Per --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > Yeah, my wording was a bit unfortunate. Here's proof that length 7 is *no* guarantee for optimality: U' R U' B U B' R' can be achieved shorter with F R' F' R U' Cheers! 480. Re: Christmas Challenge FMC
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tue, 27 Dec 2005 23:16:51 -0000

Hi everyone, good point, I did not consider it too carefully. Please correct me if I am wrong Gilles, for it's pretty likely... I think what happens is that you are allowed to create any 1x2x3 blocks as long as they finish up situated in the same position with respect to the cube itself, not the colours. On the page http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Step_2.html Gilles tells us "The number of moves can be reduced by choosing the easiest 1x2x3 block belonging to R-side." This suggests to me that you are allowed to choose any of the 4 possible 1x2x3 blocks which you could build opposite the first 1x2x3 block. However, in practice, I'm sure it is far easier to (and as Gilles also implies) analyse the 3rd step if you make the 1x2x3 blocks match up nicely. And it looks nicer. So it is for this aesthetic reason that I have decided that for the event "solve 2 Roux blocks" I would like the 2 blocks to finish up in a completely solved position. This means they have to be on opposite faces, and they have to be totally aligned with the centres, and they must both sit on the bottom of the cube. Please see the diagram here: http://grrroux.free.fr/method/steps_2.gif - to see this visually. I will add this to the FMC page, I realise that this probably isn't true Roux blocks but that's the final word. Dan :) --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Cyril Castella" <cyrilca@c...> wrote: > > I do not cube following Gilles' method, but I propose to assume that > we are all experts with it :-) > I mean, color neutrality is part of Gilles' secret, so I would propose > that we are allowed to build non-color-matched opposite blocks as > well. But the last word will be up to Dan ... or Gilles ;) ? > Gilles, Per meant that your 2x3x1 block (say you built it on L face) > does not have to be aligned with F, U,B and D centers. > Btw, THANK YOU DAN for this scramble :) After the horrible team FMC > scramble, that one seems much more promising !! > Good luck everyone ! > cyril > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, Gilles van den Peereboom > <gillesvdp@g...> wrote: > > > > how could you build a Roux Block without the center ? > > > > Gilles. > > > > 2005/12/27, Per Kristen Fredlund <aspiring_to_love@y...>: > > > Hi :-) > > > > > > I would assume both matching and aligned is required. I assume > it's > > > not necessary to align the blocks wrt the centres, only wrt to > each > > > other. > > > > > > Cheers! > > > > > > -Per > > > > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "c_w_tsai" > > > <c_w_tsai@y...> wrote: > > > > > > > > Dan, > > > > > > > > For Roux blocks, do you want them to be matching and aligned or > is > > > non- > > > > matching and non-aligned OK? > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > Yahoo! Groups Links > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > > >
481. Re: Christmas Challenge FMC
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 12:31:36 -0000

--- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > So it is for this aesthetic reason that I have decided that for the > event "solve 2 Roux blocks" I would like the 2 blocks to finish up > in a completely solved position. This means they have to be on > opposite faces, and they have to be totally aligned with the > centres, and they must both sit on the bottom of the cube. Please > see the diagram here: http://grrroux.free.fr/method/steps_2.gif - to > see this visually. Dan, your description says all six centers must be solved, but in Gilles' method it's only the L and R centers, which is also emphasized in the picture you linked to. So please clarify what you mean. I vote for L/R centers only (in addition to matching blocks). The result should look like the result in the six applets on the bottom of this page: http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Step_2.html (except using a different color scheme, of course) Cheers! Stefan
482. Re: Christmas Challenge FMC
From: "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wed, 28 Dec 2005 20:42:37 -0000

Hi Stefan :-) Good point. I also found the diagram didn't really match what dan had said. In the spirit of the roux method i also suggest that the result should look like on the bottom of the page Stefan referred to. This implies that only 2 centres need be aligned with the blocks. Those 2 centers that belong to the 2 faces where the 2 1x2x3 blocks are built :-) Have fun! -Per > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> > wrote: > > > > So it is for this aesthetic reason that I have decided that for the > > event "solve 2 Roux blocks" I would like the 2 blocks to finish up > > in a completely solved position. This means they have to be on > > opposite faces, and they have to be totally aligned with the > > centres, and they must both sit on the bottom of the cube. Please > > see the diagram here: http://grrroux.free.fr/method/steps_2.gif - to > > see this visually. > > Dan, > > your description says all six centers must be solved, but in Gilles' > method it's only the L and R centers, which is also emphasized in the > picture you linked to. 483. Re: Christmas Challenge FMC
From: "Dan" <dan_j_harris@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 15:30:02 -0000

Hi everybody, Just to clarify this point then, I would like solution to the 2 Roux blocks events to end up solving the cube to a state like the one shown on this webpage http://www.cubestation.co.uk/rouxblocks.html - where the blocks are in the positions they would be if the cube was solved completely. I realise that this isn't quite how Gilles would need to position the blocks in his method, but I think it is more aesthetically pleasing to have it this way. Submitting anything else, to my mind, is similar to submitting a pseudo 2x2x2 block for the 2x2x2 event. However, for the events we had last year, I wasn't so strict. So for one layer it is not necessary to align the centres correctly, but only to have one layer solved. And of course for one face, the only requirement is that one complete face is solved :) Good Luck everybody! Dan :) P.S. I've even had a go this time! So if you are thinking that you won't submit, at least do it to beat me! --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > Hi Stefan :-) > > Good point. I also found the diagram didn't really match what dan > had said. In the spirit of the roux method i also suggest that the > result should look like on the bottom of the page Stefan referred > to. This implies that only 2 centres need be aligned with the > blocks. Those 2 centers that belong to the 2 faces where the 2 1x2x3 > blocks are built :-) > > Have fun! > > -Per > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" > <dan_j_harris@n...> > > wrote: > > > > > > So it is for this aesthetic reason that I have decided that for > the > > > event "solve 2 Roux blocks" I would like the 2 blocks to finish > up > > > in a completely solved position. This means they have to be on > > > opposite faces, and they have to be totally aligned with the > > > centres, and they must both sit on the bottom of the cube. > Please > > > see the diagram here: http://grrroux.free.fr/method/steps_2.gif - > to > > > see this visually. > > > > Dan, > > > > your description says all six centers must be solved, but in > Gilles' > > method it's only the L and R centers, which is also emphasized in > the > > picture you linked to. So please clarify what you mean. I vote for > L/R > > centers only (in addition to matching blocks). The result should > look > > like the result in the six applets on the bottom of this page: > > http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Step_2.html > > (except using a different color scheme, of course) > > > > Cheers! > > Stefan > > >
484. Re: Christmas Challenge FMC
From: "Stefan Pochmann" <pochmann@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thu, 29 Dec 2005 20:25:59 -0000

Dan, can we have a vote on this? I think your new definitions are counterintuitive and it means I've wasted time for something that's not good and I could imagine I'm not the only one. If you call it "Roux" blocks, then it should be like the Roux method. Aligning the M-slice centers that early is *not* part of the Roux method. I also don't find it more aestetical. To the contrary, the true two Roux blocks are two nice blocks. What you suggest is something with ugly holes (at DF and DB). On the other hand, at least most methods that start by solving one layer will align the layer with the four centers touching that layer. Usually they start by first solving the edges relative to each other, then adjusting with four centers around, then solve the corners. Or vice versa with corners first. Cheers! Stefan --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" <dan_j_harris@n...> wrote: > > Hi everybody, > > Just to clarify this point then, I would like solution to the 2 Roux > blocks events to end up solving the cube to a state like the one > shown on this webpage > > http://www.cubestation.co.uk/rouxblocks.html - where the blocks are > in the positions they would be if the cube was solved completely. > > I realise that this isn't quite how Gilles would need to position > the blocks in his method, but I think it is more aesthetically > pleasing to have it this way. Submitting anything else, to my mind, > is similar to submitting a pseudo 2x2x2 block for the 2x2x2 event. > > However, for the events we had last year, I wasn't so strict. So for > one layer it is not necessary to align the centres correctly, but > only to have one layer solved. And of course for one face, the only > requirement is that one complete face is solved :) > > Good Luck everybody! Dan :) > > P.S. I've even had a go this time! So if you are thinking that you > won't submit, at least do it to beat me! > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Per Kristen Fredlund" > <aspiring_to_love@y...> wrote: > > > > Hi Stefan :-) > > > > Good point. I also found the diagram didn't really match what dan > > had said. In the spirit of the roux method i also suggest that the > > result should look like on the bottom of the page Stefan referred > > to. This implies that only 2 centres need be aligned with the > > blocks. Those 2 centers that belong to the 2 faces where the 2 > 1x2x3 > > blocks are built :-) > > > > Have fun! > > > > -Per > > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Stefan Pochmann" > > <pochmann@g...> wrote: > > > > > > --- In fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com, "Dan" > > <dan_j_harris@n...> > > > wrote: > > > > > > > > So it is for this aesthetic reason that I have decided that > for > > the > > > > event "solve 2 Roux blocks" I would like the 2 blocks to > finish > > up > > > > in a completely solved position. This means they have to be on > > > > opposite faces, and they have to be totally aligned with the > > > > centres, and they must both sit on the bottom of the cube. > > Please > > > > see the diagram here: > http://grrroux.free.fr/method/steps_2.gif - > > to > > > > see this visually. > > > > > > Dan, > > > > > > your description says all six centers must be solved, but in > > Gilles' > > > method it's only the L and R centers, which is also emphasized > in > > the > > > picture you linked to. So please clarify what you mean. I vote > for > > L/R > > > centers only (in addition to matching blocks). The result should > > look > > > like the result in the six applets on the bottom of this page: > > > http://grrroux.free.fr/method/Step_2.html > > > (except using a different color scheme, of course) > > > > > > Cheers! > > > Stefan > > > > > >

To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: 29 Dec 2005 20:35:24 -0000

Enter your vote today! A new poll has been created for the fewestmoveschallenge group: About "two Roux blocks". Only answer if you have found a solution already! Did you purposely (i.e. not by accident) align the M-slice centers with the two blocks? In other words, did you think the task includes this alignment? o yes o no To vote, please visit the following web page: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/fewestmoveschallenge/surveys?id=12220847 Note: Please do not reply to this message. Poll votes are not collected via email. To vote, you must go to the Yahoo! Groups web site listed above. Thanks!

491. Re: [fewestmoveschallenge] Re: Christmas Challenge FMC
From: Jason Kovacic <kovacic81@...>
To: fewestmoveschallenge@yahoogroups.com
Date: Sat, 31 Dec 2005 13:24:09 -0800 (PST)

In my opinion Centers being matched up should not be a factor. I use this system exclusively, and I don't think that centers need to be in place. When finishing B2, you can make an R and r or vice versa to put Red/Orange on top. As long as REd or Orange is on top, you can recognize Edge Orientation quickly and easlily. There is no reason in the world to align centers after B1. Bottom Line; Step 4 fixes last 6 edges and Centers. You will mess up the centers *Guaranteed* during execution of step 4. IT's all M and U moves! So to Iterate, In my opinion, centers defenitely dont need to be aligned for either B1 or B2. Its one of the great advantages of the ROUX method to have the M slice Free. Happy CUbing JASON Kovacic c_w_tsai <c_w_tsai@...> wrote: > I was not at home this week. It seems I'm coming back a little to >late > to give my opinion on this interesting subject :-) Go ahead and give your opionion anyway :) I'd like to know. It's your method, you know .... but it's Dan's contest :P SPONSORED LINKS Jigsaw puzzle game Free puzzle inlay games Educational game and puzzle Word puzzle game Kid puzzle game Puzzle games --------------------------------- YAHOO!
